revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Angels & Demons | image = angels_and_demons.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Ron Howard]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[John Calley]] * [[Brian Grazer]] * Ron Howard }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * [[Akiva Goldsman]] * [[David Koepp]] }} | based on = {{Based on|''[[Angels & Demons]]''|[[Dan Brown]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Tom Hanks]] * [[Ewan McGregor]] * [[Ayelet Zurer]] * [[Stellan Skarsgård]] * [[Pierfrancesco Favino]] * [[Nikolaj Lie Kaas]] * [[Armin Mueller-Stahl]] }} | narrator = [[Alfred Molina]] | music = [[Hans Zimmer]]<!-- http://scorenotes.com/hans_james_2008.html--> | cinematography = [[Salvatore Totino]] | editing = {{Plainlist| * [[Daniel P. Hanley]] * [[Mike Hill (film editor)|Mike Hill]] }} | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Imagine Entertainment]] * Panorama Films * Skylark Productions }} | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2009|05|4|[[Rome]]|2009|05|15|United States}} | runtime = 138 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 138:15--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/angels-demons-2009-0 | title=''ANGELS & DEMONS'' (12A) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=April 17, 2009 | accessdate=January 12, 2016}}</ref> Extended: 146 Minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $150 million<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3ibd965fb07c29611127bbd20be2ac1226 |title='Angels & Demons' hauls $48 million |author=DiOrio, Carl |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc]] |date=May 17, 2009 |accessdate=January 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521083940/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3ibd965fb07c29611127bbd20be2ac1226 |archivedate=May 21, 2009 }}</ref> | gross = $485.9 million<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=angelsanddemons.htm |title=Angels & Demons (2009) |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=October 28, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091010203211/http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=angelsanddemons.htm| archivedate= October 10, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> }} '''''Angels & Demons''''' is a 2009 American [[Mystery film|mystery]] [[horror film|horror]] [[Thriller film|thriller]] film directed by [[Ron Howard]] and written by [[Akiva Goldsman]] and [[David Koepp]], based on [[Dan Brown]]'s [[Angels & Demons|novel of the same title]]. It is the [[sequel]] to the 2006 film ''[[The Da Vinci Code (film)|The Da Vinci Code]]'', also directed by Howard, and the second installment in the [[Robert Langdon (film series)|''Robert Langdon'' film series]]. The novel was published first and ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'' novel followed it. Filming took place in [[Rome]], [[Italy]], and the [[Sony Pictures Studios]] in [[Culver City, California]]. [[Tom Hanks]] reprises his role as Professor [[Robert Langdon]]. Producer [[Brian Grazer]], composer [[Hans Zimmer]] and screenwriter [[Akiva Goldsman]] also return, with [[David Koepp]] coming on board to help the latter.
The film grossed $485 million worldwide.<ref name="auto"/> A sequel, titled ''[[Inferno (2016 film)|Inferno]]'', was released on October 28, 2016.
==Plot== At [[CERN]], Father Silvano and Dr. Vittoria Verna create three canisters of [[antimatter]]. Silvano is murdered, and one of the canisters is stolen. The [[Roman Catholic Church]] mourn the sudden death of [[Pope]] Pius XVI, and prepare for the [[papal conclave]] to elect his successor in [[Vatican City]]. Father Patrick McKenna, the [[Camerlengo of the Holy Roman Church|Camerlengo]], takes control of the Vatican. Four of the “preferiti”, the favoured candidates to be Pope, are kidnapped by a man claiming to represent the [[Illuminati]]. He sends the Vatican a warning, claiming he will murder each of the cardinals from 8pm to midnight, where the stolen antimatter will explode and destroy the city, hidden somewhere within.
American [[symbologist]] Professor [[Robert Langdon]] is brought to the Vatican to help. He deduces that the four cardinals will be murdered on the four altars of the “Path of Illumination”, in locations relevant to the [[classical elements]]. McKenna gives Langdon access to the [[Vatican Secret Archives]] to research the altars, against the wishes of Commander Richter, head of the [[Swiss Guard]]. He and Vittoria examine [[Galileo Galilei]]’s [[Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems|banned book]], following clues to the [[Chigi Chapel]], accompanied by Ernesto Olivetti and Claudio Vincenzi of the [[Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City]]. They find Cardinal Eber dead, branded with the ambigrammatic word “Earth”.
The second, Cardinal Lamassé, is murdered in [[St. Peter’s Square]], his lungs punctured and branded with “Air”. Vittoria suspects the Pope was actually murdered via overdose, she and McKenna confirming this by secretly inspecting his body. Langdon, Olivetti, and Vincenzi eventually identify the [[Santa Maria della Vittoria, Rome|Santa Maria della Vittoria]] as the altar of fire, finding Cardinal Guidera burning to death, branded with “Fire”. The assassin appears, killing Olivetti and Vincenzi, before escaping to drown Cardinal Baggia in the [[Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi]]. Langdon and civilians intervene, rescuing Baggia, who tells Langdon the preferiti were held in [[Castel Sant’Angelo]].
Richter confiscates Dr. Silvano’s journals, Vittoria convinced that he is a conspirator. Langdon, Vittoria, and the police storm Castel Sant’Angelo. Langdon and Vittoria find the assassin’s lair, discovering five brands, the last meant for McKenna. The assassin escapes, claiming his contractors are “men of God”. Guided to a car by his unseen contractor, the assassin dies [[Car bomb|when the vehicle explodes]] upon ignition. Langdon and Vittoria find a secret passageway leading to the Vatican, warning the Swiss Guard of McKenna’s fate. They find Richter hovering over a branded McKenna. He, and Archbishop Simeon, an alleged conspirator, are killed. Langdon retrieves a key from the dying Richter’s hand.
The antimatter container is found in [[Saint Peter's tomb]], but will detonate in five minutes, the cold temperature preventing its battery from being charged in time. McKenna flees the Vatican with the canister, piloting a [[helicopter]] into the sky, then parachutes out seconds before the antimatter detonates. McKenna is hailed as a hero, with calls for him to be elected as Pope.
Langdon and Vittoria retrieve Silvano’s journals from Richter’s office, finding he kept tabs on the Pope with hidden security cameras. They find footage of Richter confronting McKenna, revealing the Camerlengo is the mastermind behind the attacks. The Pope had invited Silvano to publicly present the antimatter as proof of a divine power, bridging the gap between religion and science. Considering such a claim blasphemy, McKenna orchestrated the Pope’s death, and the Illuminati assassin, then plotted to be elected as Pope. The footage is shown to the papal conclave. McKenna, realising he has been exposed, commits suicide via [[self-immolation]].
The Vatican announces McKenna died from injuries from his parachute landing, and Baggia is elected as Pope Luke I. Cardinal Strauss, the Pope’s new Camerlengo, gives Langdon the “Diagramma Veritatis” as thanks for his help, and to complete his scholarly work on Galileo. The new Pope gives Langdon and Vittoria a thankful nod, before stepping out on the balcony to greet the crowd below.
==Cast== {{see also|List of Angels & Demons characters}} {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Tom Hanks]] as [[Robert Langdon]], a [[Harvard University]] professor of [[symbology]]. * [[Ewan McGregor]] as Father Patrick McKenna, the [[Camerlengo of the Holy Roman Church|Camerlengo]]. * [[Ayelet Zurer]] as Dr. Vittoria Vetra, a [[CERN]] scientist whose [[antimatter]] experiment has been stolen by the [[Illuminati]]. * [[Stellan Skarsgård]] as Commander Maximilian Richter, head of the [[Swiss Guard]]. * [[Pierfrancesco Favino]] as Inspector General Ernesto Olivetti of the [[Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City|Gendarme Corps of Vatican City State]]. * [[Nikolaj Lie Kaas]] as The Assassin * [[Armin Mueller-Stahl]] as Cardinal Strauss, [[Dean of the College of Cardinals]] and the Papal Conclave. * [[Thure Lindhardt]] as Lieutenant Chartrand, officer of the [[Swiss Guard]]. * [[David Pasquesi]] as Claudio Vincenzi, a Vatican police officer sent to summon Langdon. * [[Cosimo Fusco]] as Archbishop Simeon, Prefect of the Papal Household. * [[Victor Alfieri]] as Lieutenant Valenti, a [[Carabinieri]] officer who takes Langdon to the [[Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi|Fountain of the Four Rivers]]. * [[Carmen Argenziano]] as Father Silvano Bentivoglio, a [[Catholic priest]] and a [[CERN]] scientist who performed the [[antimatter]] experiment along with Dr. Vetra. * Marco Fiorini as Cardinal Baggia/Pope Luke I, one of the four [[Papabile|Preferiti]] and a cardinal from [[Milan]], Italy and the favorite to succeed as the new pope. * [[Bob Yerkes]] as Cardinal Guidera, one of the four Preferiti and a cardinal from [[Barcelona]], Spain. * Franklin Amobi as Cardinal Lamassé, one of the four Preferiti and a cardinal from Paris, France. * [[Curt Lowens]] as Cardinal Ebner, one of the four Preferiti and a cardinal from [[Frankfurt]], Germany. * Todd Schneider as a [[Carabiniere]], Lieutenant Valenti's partner who along with him takes Langdon to the [[Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi|Fountain of the Four Rivers]]. * [[Anna Katarina]] as Docent, the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]] tour guide who tells Langdon the name of the first church. * Howard Mungo as Cardinal Yoruba * [[Rance Howard]] as Cardinal Beck * [[Steve Franken]] as Cardinal Colbert * [[Gino Conforti]] as Cardinal Pugini * [[Elya Baskin]] as Cardinal Petrov {{div col end}}
==Production==
===Development=== In 2003, Sony Pictures acquired the film rights to ''[[Angels & Demons]]'' along with ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'' in a deal with author [[Dan Brown]]. In May 2006, following the release of [[The Da Vinci Code (film)|the 2006 film adaptation of ''The Da Vinci Code'']], Sony Pictures hired screenwriter [[Akiva Goldsman]], who wrote the film adaptation of ''The Da Vinci Code'', to adapt ''Angels & Demons''.<ref>{{cite news|author=Michael Fleming |url=http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=features2006&content=jump&jump=story&dept=cannes&nav=NCannes&articleid=VR1117943968&cs=1 |title=Brown's "Angels" flies to bigscreen |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=May 23, 2006 |accessdate=December 20, 2006}}</ref> Filming was originally to begin in February 2008 and was originally going to be released on December 19, 2008,<ref>{{cite news|author=Michael Fleming | title=Howard moves fast with "Code" sequel |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=October 24, 2007 |url=http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=print_story&articleid=VR1117974685&categoryid=1236 |accessdate=October 31, 2007}}</ref> but because of the [[2007–2008 Writers Guild of America strike]], the film was pushed back for May 15, 2009.<ref>{{cite news|author=Tatiana Siegel |title="Da Vinci" prequel hit by strike |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=November 16, 2007 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117976189.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |accessdate=November 17, 2007}}</ref> [[David Koepp]] rewrote the script before shooting began.<ref>{{cite news|author=Tatiana Siegel |title=Koepp hopes to keep "Town" rolling |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=June 11, 2008 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117988832.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |accessdate=October 30, 2008}}</ref>
Director [[Ron Howard]] chose to treat ''Angels & Demons'' as a sequel to the previous film, rather than a [[prequel]], since many had read the novel after ''The Da Vinci Code''. He liked the idea that Langdon had been through one adventure and become a more confident character.<ref name="empire">{{cite news|author=[[Ian Freer]] |title=Critical Mass |work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]] |date = May 2009|pages=69–73}}</ref> Howard was also more comfortable taking liberties in adapting the story because the novel is less popular than ''The Da Vinci Code''.<ref name="arrested">{{cite news|author=Edward Douglas |title=Ron Howard on Arrested Development and Angels & Demons |work=ComingSoon.net |date=November 13, 2008 |url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=50497 |accessdate=November 13, 2008}}</ref> Producer [[Brian Grazer]] said they were too "reverential" when adapting ''The Da Vinci Code'', which resulted in it being "a little long and stagey." This time, "Langdon doesn't stop and give a speech. When he speaks, he's in motion."<ref name="faster">{{cite news|author=Scott Bowles |title=First look: "Angels & Demons" will fly faster than "Da Vinci" |work=[[USA Today]] |date=October 17, 2008 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2008-10-27-angels-demons_N.htm?loc=interstitialskip |accessdate=October 28, 2008}}</ref> Howard concurred "it's very much about modernity clashing with antiquity and technology vs. faith, so these themes, these ideas are much more active whereas the other one lived so much in the past. The tones are just innately so different between the two stories."<ref name=arrested/>
===Differences between novel and film=== * In the novel, the papal conclave attracts relatively little public attention. In the wake of the huge international interest in the [[Papal conclave, 2005|2005 election]] of [[Pope Benedict XVI]], this was judged to be out of date.<ref>{{cite web| last = Hanks| first = Tom| author2 = interviewed by Charlie Rose| title = A conversation about the film "Angels and Demons"| publisher = PBS television (transcript)| date = May 13, 2009| url = http://www.charlierose.com/view/interview/10294#frame_top| accessdate = June 12, 2009| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090517111531/http://www.charlierose.com/view/interview/10294#frame_top| archivedate = May 17, 2009| deadurl = yes| df = mdy-all}}</ref> The character of CERN Director Maximillian Kohler does not appear in the film. The Italian Camerlengo Carlo Ventresca is changed to the Irish Patrick McKenna, portrayed by [[Ewan McGregor]]. The [[Boeing X-33]] that takes Langdon from the United States to Geneva and then to Rome is absent in the film. In the novel, Commander Olivetti is the commander of [[Swiss Guard]], and his second in command is Captain Rocher, whereas in the film, Richter is the head of the Swiss Guard. In the novel, the Assassin contacts members of the BBC in order to influence how they present the story of his activities, but this does not happen in the film. The character Leonardo Vetra is named Silvano Bentivoglio in the film, is not related to Vittoria and his death scene is changed. Vittoria is a love interest for Langdon in the novel while there is no attraction present in the film. In the novel Camerlengo Carlo Ventresca is revealed to be the late pope's biological son, while in the film he is his adoptive son.<ref>{{cite web|title=What's the Difference between Angels and Demons the Book and Angels and Demons the Movie|url=http://thatwasnotinthebook.com/diff/angels_and_demons_book_2000_vs_angels_and_demons_movie_2009|publisher=thatwasnotinthebook.com|accessdate=18 Oct 2013}}</ref> * In the film, the Camerlengo briefly acknowledges Langdon's involvement in some events of the [[The Da Vinci Code (film)|previous film]] when in the book it does not, as the events in ''The Da Vinci Code'' are yet to take place. This is due to the fact the first novel in the film series was adapted to film after the second book rather than in the order of first-to-last. * In the book, the assassin has Middle Eastern looks whereas in the movie he is portrayed by a Danish actor. In the film, he is killed by a car bomb, whereas in the book he falls from a balcony at the top of the [[Castel Sant Angelo]] and breaks his back on a pile of marble cannonballs which eventually kills him. * In the novel, Vittoria is kidnapped, whereas in the film, she accompanies Langdon almost everywhere. In the book, all four preferiti are killed by the assassin and eventually the high elector, Cardinal Saverio Mortati, is elected as the new pope, whereas in the film, the fourth preferito, Cardinal Baggia, is saved by Langdon and is elected the new pope. The high elector, renamed Cardinal Strauss, becomes the Camerlengo to the new pope. * In the book, the fifth brand is one that incorporates all four words from the previous four, whereas in the film, the fifth brand is the crossed keys, symbolic of the Papacy. * The means by which the heroes discover the location of the bomb is significantly different. In the book, the Camerlengo feigns a religious vision from god, telling him where to find the bomb. In the film, he feeds Langdon a clue to the bomb's location by branding himself with an upside-down version of the papal keys, which Langdon successfully deduces is a metaphor for [[Saint Peter]], the first pope, who was crucified upside-down. * In the book, Langdon stows away on the Camerlengo's helicopter, and just before the antimatter explosion, jumps out using a makeshift parachute, and lands on [[Isola Tiberina]], whose mythical healing powers heal the injuries he incurs from the fall. In the film, Langdon does not get on the helicopter. * In the book's closing scenes, a Swiss Guard hands Langdon the fifth brand, the Illuminati diamond, as a gift. In the film, the new Camerlengo hands over Galileo's book to Langdon.
===Filming=== [[Principal photography|Shooting]] began on June 4, 2008, in Rome under the [[title ruse|fake working title]] ''Obelisk''.<ref name="stop">{{cite news|author=Elisabetta Povoledo |title=Dan Brown Tourists: Next Stop, Rome? |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 24, 2008 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/24/movies/24ange.html?ref=movies |accessdate=August 26, 2008}}</ref> The filmmakers scheduled three weeks of exterior location filming because of a predicted [[2008 Screen Actors Guild strike]] on June 30. The rest of the film would be shot at Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, California, to allow for this halt.<ref>{{cite news|author=Pamela McClintock, Michael Fleming |title=Film greenlights in limbo |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=February 27, 2008 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117981560.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |accessdate=February 28, 2008}}</ref> Roman Catholic Church officials found ''The Da Vinci Code'' offensive and forbade filming in their churches, so these scenes were shot at Sony.<ref name=stop/> The [[Caserta Palace]] doubled for the inside of the Vatican,<ref name=stop/> and the [[Angelica Library|Biblioteca Angelica]] was used for the [[Vatican Library]].<ref>{{cite news|title=ET on the top secret "Angels & Demons" set! |work=[[Entertainment Tonight]] |date=September 9, 2008 |url=http://www.etonline.com/news/2008/09/65273/ |accessdate=September 13, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006075352/http://www.etonline.com/news/2008/09/65273/ |archivedate=October 6, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Filming took place at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] in July.<ref>{{cite news|title=ANGELS AND DEMONS was Filming Today at UCLA in Los Angeles |work=Collider |date=July 10, 2008 |url=http://www.collider.com/entertainment/news/article.asp/aid/8439/tcid/1 |accessdate=September 13, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081006021821/http://www.collider.com/entertainment/news/article.asp/aid/8439/tcid/1| archivedate= October 6, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Sony and [[Imagine Entertainment]] organized an eco-friendly shoot, selecting when to shoot locations based on how much time and fuel it would save, using cargo containers to support set walls or [[chroma key|greenscreens]], as well as storing props for future productions or donating them to charity.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.angelsanddemons.com/site/entry.php#story |title=A Green Production |work=Official site |accessdate=March 28, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216204925/http://angelsanddemons.com/site/entry.php |archivedate=February 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
[[File:Angels&DemonsPantheon.JPG|thumb|Ayelet Zurer and Tom Hanks outside the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]]]] Howard hated that the Writers Guild strike forced him to delay shooting the film until summer. However, the quick shoot allowed him to refine the [[naturalism (theatre)|naturalism]] he had employed on his previous film ''[[Frost/Nixon (film)|Frost/Nixon]]'', often using handheld cameras to lend an additional energy to the scenes.
Hanks interrupted filming of one scene in order to help Australian bride Natalia Dearnley get through the crowds to her wedding on time.<ref>[http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=815244 Hanks saves Aussie bride], [[Nine News]]. Published May 19, 2009. Retrieved September 13, 2010.</ref> McGregor said the Pope's funeral was the dullest sequence to film, as they were just walking across staircases. Then, "Someone started singing '[[Bohemian Rhapsody]]' [and] it became the funeral theme tune."<ref name="empire"/>
When recreating the interior of [[St. Peter's Basilica]], production designer Allan Cameron and visual effects supervisor Angus Bickerton recognized the {{cvt|80|ft|m}} tall soundstages were only half the size of the real church. They rebuilt the area around and the crypts beneath [[St. Peter's baldachin]], including the bottoms of the columns and [[Saint Peter]]'s statue, and surrounded it with a 360 degree greenscreen so the rest could be built digitally. Cameron had twenty crew members, posing as members of the public, photograph as much as they could inside the [[Sistine Chapel]], and had artists sketch, photograph and enlarge recreations of the paintings and mosaics from the photographs. Cameron chose to present the Sistine Chapel as it was before [[Restoration of the Sistine Chapel frescoes|the restoration of its frescoes]], because he preferred the contrast the smoky, muted colors would present with the cardinals. Although the chapel was built to full size, the [[Sala Regia (Vatican)|Sala Regia]] was made smaller to fit inside the stage.<ref name="location">{{cite web|title=On Location |work=Official website |url=http://www.angelsanddemons.com/site/entry.php#location |accessdate=March 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216204925/http://angelsanddemons.com/site/entry.php |archivedate=February 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
The [[Saint Peter's Square]] and the [[Piazza Navona]] sets were built on the same [[backlot]]; after completion of scenes at the former, six weeks were spent converting the set, knocking down the Basilica side and excavating {{cvt|3+1/2|ft|m|0}} of tarmac to build the fountain. As there had been filming at the real Piazza Navona, the transition between it and the replica had to be seamless. To present the [[Santa Maria del Popolo]] undergoing renovation, a police station in Rome opposite the real church was used for the exterior; the scaffolding would hide that it was not the church. Cameron built the interior of Santa Maria del Popolo on the same set as the recreated [[Santa Maria della Vittoria, Rome|Santa Maria della Vittoria]] to save money; the scaffolding also disguised this. The film's version of Santa Maria della Vittoria was larger than the real one, so it would accommodate the cranes used to film the scene. To film the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon's]] interior, two [[aedicula]]e and the tomb of [[Raphael]] were rebuilt to scale at a height of {{cvt|30|ft|m|0}}, while the rest was greenscreen. Because of the building's symmetrical layout, the filmmakers were able to shoot the whole scene over two days and [[redress]] the real side to pretend it was another.<ref name=location/> The [[second unit]] took photographs of the [[Large Hadron Collider]] and pasted these in scenes set at [[CERN]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Perkins|first1=Ceri|title=ATLAS gets the Hollywood treatment|url=http://atlas-service-enews.web.cern.ch/atlas-service-enews/2007-8/news_07-8/news_angelphoto.php|website=ATLAS e-News|publisher=CERN|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref>
==Music== {{Infobox album | name = Angels & Demons: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack | type = Soundtrack | artist = Hans Zimmer | cover = | alt = | released = May 22, 2009 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Soundtrack | length = | label = [[Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc.]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} '''''Angels & Demons: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack''''' was released on May 22, 2009.<ref>[https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/angels-demons-original-motion/id316986348 Angels & Demons (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)]. ''[[iTunes]]''. Retrieved October 22, 2010.</ref>
[[Hans Zimmer]] returned to compose the score for the sequel. He chose to develop the "Chevaliers de Sangreal" track from the end of ''The Da Vinci Code'' as Langdon's main theme in the film, featuring prominently in the tracks "God Particle " and "503". The soundtrack also features violinist [[Joshua Bell]].
{{Track listing | title1 = 160 BPM | length1 = 6:41 | title2 = God Particle | length2 = 5:20 | title3 = Air | length3 = 9:07 | title4 = Fire | length4 = 6:51 | title5 = Black Smoke | length5 = 5:45 | title6 = Science and Religion | length6 = 12:27 | title7 = Immolation | length7 = 3:39 | title8 = Election By Adoration | length8 = 2:12 | title9 = 503 | length9 = 2:14 | title10 = H2O (Bonus downloadable track) | length10 = 1:51
}}
==Home media and different versions== The DVD was released on November 24, 2009 in several countries as a theatrical version and extended cut.
''Angels and Demons'' was also released on UMD for the Sony PlayStation Portable (PSP) on October 21, 2009.
The extended cut includes violent scenes which had been cut out to secure a PG-13 rating.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} In the UK, the already censored US theatrical version had to be censored further in order to obtain a BBFC 12A rating.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} The Blu-ray includes the original theatrical version and is classified BBFC 15.
==Reception== ===Box office=== Overseas, ''Angels & Demons'' maintained the #1 position for the second weekend as well even with the release of ''[[Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian]]'', which opened at #2. The film opened with $46 million at the domestic box office. ''The Da Vinci Code'' had opened domestically to $77.1 million, but the sequel's opening met Columbia's $40–50 million prediction, since the film's source material was not as popular as its predecessor's. Within more than a month, the film grossed $478,869,160 worldwide, making it the largest-grossing film of 2009 until it was surpassed by ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]''.<ref>{{cite news |title="Angels & Demons" flies high at box office (Reuters) |work=[[Yahoo! Movies]] |date=May 17, 2009 |url=https://movies.yahoo.com/news/movies.reuters.com/quotangels-demonsquot-flies-high-box-office-reuters |accessdate=May 17, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090521211842/http://movies.yahoo.com/news/movies.reuters.com/quotangels-demonsquot-flies-high-box-office-reuters| archivedate= May 21, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Frank Segers |title=New 'Transformers' bows No. 1 overseas |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=June 21, 2009 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i34e2ede5adb7e1e8e8cbf7a6dbae2373 |accessdate=June 22, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090625060306/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i34e2ede5adb7e1e8e8cbf7a6dbae2373| archivedate= June 25, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Of this $478 million, just over 27% of it is from domestic venues, giving the film high worldwide totals, with over $30 million in the UK, $21 million in Spain, $13 million in Brazil, $13 million in Russia, $34 million in Japan, and $47 million in Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=angelsanddemons.htm|title=Angels & Demons (2009) - International Box Office Results - Box Office Mojo|website=www.boxofficemojo.com}}</ref> ''Angels & Demons'' was the ninth-highest-grossing film of 2009, with box-office figures of $485,930,810 worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|title=2009 Worldwide Grosses|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=2009&p=.htm|publisher=IMDb|accessdate=April 7, 2012}}</ref>
===Critical response=== Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported that 37% of 249 critics have given the film a positive review, with an average rating of 5.1/10. The site's general consensus is that "''Angels and Demons'' is a fast-paced thrill ride, and an improvement on the last Dan Brown adaptation, but the storyline too often wavers between implausible and ridiculous, and does not translate effectively to the big screen."<ref name=RT>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1189217-angels_and_demons/ |title=Angels & Demons (2009) |accessdate=May 3, 2012 |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | work=[[IGN Entertainment]]}}</ref> [[Metacritic]] has a rating score of 48 out of 100 based on 36 reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/angelsanddemons |title=Angels & Demons (2009): Reviews |accessdate=May 2, 2010 |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |work=[[CNET Networks]] }}</ref> [[BBC]] critic [[Mark Kermode]] criticized the film's "silliness", saying "Whereas the original movie featured Hanks standing around in darkened rooms explaining the plot to anyone who was still awake, this second salvo cranks up the action by having Tom explain the plot while running—a major breakthrough."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kermode|first1=Mark|title=Angels & Demons|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/sep/13/mark-kermode-crank2-high-voltage|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref>
Richard Corliss of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] gave the film a positive review, stating that "''Angels & Demons'' has elemental satisfactions in its blend of movie genre that could appeal to wide segments of the audience."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1897543,00.html |title=Review: Holy Hanks! Fun and Games in ''Angels & Demons'' |publisher=TIME Magazine |date=May 13, 2009 |accessdate=May 16, 2009 |first=Richard |last=Corliss |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090516163733/http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0%2C8599%2C1897543%2C00.html |archivedate=May 16, 2009 |deadurl=no }}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' awarded the film three stars, praising Howard's direction as an "even-handed job of balancing the scales" and claiming "[the film] promises to entertain."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090513/REVIEWS/905139997 |title=Angels and Demons :: rogerebert.com :: review |publisher=Chicago Sun-Times |accessdate=May 14, 2009 |date=May 16, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518004508/http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20090513%2FREVIEWS%2F905139997 |archivedate=May 18, 2009 |deadurl=no }}</ref> ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' gave the film a positive review, claiming the movie is "an OK [[action film]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/0515/p17s01-almo.html |title=Review: "Angels and Demons" - the Christian Science Monitor |date=May 15, 2009 |accessdate=May 16, 2009 |publisher=Christian Science Monitor| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090517091051/http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/0515/p17s01-almo.html| archivedate= May 17, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Peter Travers of ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'' gave the film two-and-a-half out of four stars claiming "the movie can be enjoyed for the hell-raising hooey it is."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/12615902/review/28221175/angels__demons |title=Angels & Demons : Review : Rolling Stone |publisher=Rolling Stone |accessdate=May 16, 2009 |date=May 14, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090516205625/http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/12615902/review/28221175/angels__demons| archivedate= May 16, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Joe Morgenstern of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' gave the film a mixed review, claiming it "manages to keep you partially engaged even at its most esoteric or absurd."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/film_review.html |title=Plot's Knots Bedevil "Angels" |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=May 16, 2009 | first=Joe | last=Morgenstern| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090430215409/http://online.wsj.com/article/film_review.html| archivedate= April 30, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Neil Smith from ''[[Total Film]]'' gave the film four out of five stars, saying "some of the author's crazier embellishments are jettisoned in a film that atones for The Da Vinci Code's cardinal sin — thou shalt not bore."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.totalfilm.com/reviews/cinema/angels-and-demons |title=Review |work=[[Total Film]] |publisher=Future Publishing |accessdate=May 6, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090509084151/http://www.totalfilm.com/reviews/cinema/angels-and-demons| archivedate= May 9, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Kim Newman]] awarded it three out of five stars, stating "every supporting character acts like an unhelpful idiot to keep the plot stirring, while yet again a seemingly all-powerful conspiracy seems to consist of two whole evil guys."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=134206 |title=Review |work=[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]] |accessdate=May 6, 2009}}</ref>
===Catholic Church response=== ''[[CBS News]]'' interviewed a priest working in [[Santa Susanna]], who stated the Church did not want their churches to be associated with scenes of murder. A tour guide also stated most priests do not object to tourists who visit out of interest after reading the book, a trend which will continue after people see the film. "I think they are aware that it's... a work of fiction and that it's bringing people into their churches."<ref>{{cite news|title=Fans Line Up For "Angels & Demons" Tours |work=[[CBS News]] |date=June 19, 2008 |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/06/19/earlyshow/leisure/boxoffice/main4193975.shtml |accessdate=June 19, 2008}}</ref> Grazer deemed it odd that although ''The Da Vinci Code'' was a more controversial novel, they had more freedom shooting its film adaptation in London and France.<ref name="faster"/> Italian authorities hoped the filmmakers corrected the location errors in the novel, to limit the amount of explaining they will have to do for confused tourists.<ref name=stop/>
[[William A. Donohue]], president of the [[Catholic League (U.S.)|Catholic League]], did not call for a boycott, but requested that Catholics inform others about anti-Catholic sentiments in the story. "My goal... is to give the public a big FYI: Enjoy the movie, but know that it is a fable. It is based on malicious myths, intentionally advanced by Ron Howard." A Sony executive responded that they were disappointed Donohue had not created attention for the film closer to its release date.<ref>{{cite news|author=Tatiana Siegel |title=Catholic controversy doesn't bug Sony |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=March 6, 2009 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118000940.html |accessdate=March 18, 2009| archiveurl= https://archive.is/20120915115313/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118000940.html| archivedate= September 15, 2012 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Howard criticized Donohue for prejudging the film, responding that it could not be called anti-Catholic since Langdon protects the Church, and because of its depiction of priests who support science.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Ron Howard]] |title=Angels & Demons: It's A Thriller, Not A Crusade |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=April 20, 2009 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ron-howard/iangels-demonsi-its-a-thr_b_189053.html |accessdate=April 21, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090422180718/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ron-howard/iangels-demonsi-its-a-thr_b_189053.html| archivedate= April 22, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The official Vatican newspaper ''[[L'Osservatore Romano]]'' called the film "harmless entertainment", giving it a positive review and acknowledging that "the theme is always the same: a sect versus the Church, [but] this time, the Church is on the side of the good guys."<ref>{{cite news|title=Demons "harmless", says Vatican |work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=May 7, 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8037538.stm |accessdate=May 7, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090510131825/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8037538.stm| archivedate= May 10, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/5290910/Angels-and-Demons-Vatican-breaks-silence-to-review-film.html |title=Angels and Demons: Vatican breaks silence to review film |date=May 7, 2009 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=May 7, 2009 | location=London | first=Anita | last=Singh| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090509005352/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/5290910/Angels-and-Demons-Vatican-breaks-silence-to-review-film.html| archivedate= May 9, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Beforehand, it had stated it would not approve the film, while ''[[La Stampa]]'' reported the Vatican would boycott it. However, it also quoted [[Velasio de Paolis|Archbishop Velasio De Paolis]] as saying a boycott would probably just have the "[[Streisand effect|boomerang effect]]" of drawing more attention to ''Angels & Demons'' and making it more popular.<ref>{{cite news|author=Eric J. Lyman |title="Angels & Demons" may face Vatican boycott |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=March 20, 2009 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i3a47175c45afb2f2b755c4f38e41860c?imw=Y |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324014710/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i3a47175c45afb2f2b755c4f38e41860c?imw=Y |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 24, 2009 |accessdate=March 23, 2009 |df=mdy }}</ref>
In FAQ titled ''Angels & Demons: from the Book to the Movie'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cesnur.org/2005/mi_illuminati_en.htm|title=Angels & Demons from the Book to the Movie FAQ – Do the Illuminati Really Exist?, by Massimo Introvigne|first=|last=MoreOrLess|website=www.cesnur.org}}</ref> [[Massimo Introvigne]], Director of [[CESNUR]] (Center for the Study of New Religions) points out crucial factual errors in Dan Brown's original novel and the film version. Introvigne also criticizes the Illuminati mythology that is treated as historical fact.
====Banned in Samoa==== In [[Samoa]], the film was banned by film censor Lei'ataua Olo'apu. Olo'apu stated that he was banning the film because it was "critical of the Catholic Church" and so as to "avoid any religious discrimination by other denominations and faiths against the Church." The ''Samoa Observer'' remarked that Olo'apu himself is Catholic.<ref>[http://www.samoaobserver.ws/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=8309:chief-censor&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=50 "Chief censor bans movie Angels and Demons"], ''Samoa Observer'', May 21, 2009.</ref> The Censorship Board had previously banned the film ''The Da Vinci Code'',<ref name="RNZI_24194">{{cite web |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=24194 |title=Samoa’s government censor bans Da Vinci Code film |date=May 21, 2006 |work=[[Radio New Zealand International]] |accessdate=September 19, 2011}}</ref> for being "contradictory to Christian beliefs."<ref>[http://www.radioaustralianews.net.au/stories/200904/2557247.htm?desktop "Samoa bans 'Milk' film"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219112942/http://www.radioaustralianews.net.au/stories/200904/2557247.htm?desktop |date=February 19, 2012 }}, ABC Radio Australia, April 30, 2009.</ref>
==Accolades== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- ! Award !! Category !! Recipient(s) and Nominee(s) !! Result |- | rowspan="2" | [[2009 Teen Choice Awards]] | Choice Movie: Drama | rowspan="2" | ''Angels & Demons'' | {{nom}} |- | Choice Summer Movie: Drama | {{nom}} |- |[[8th Visual Effects Society Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.visualeffectssociety.com/ayear/8th-annual-ves-awards|title=8th Annual VES Awards|work=visual effects society|accessdate=December 22, 2017}}</ref> |[[Visual Effects Society Award for Outstanding Supporting Visual Effects in a Feature Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Visual Effects in a Feature Motion Picture]] |Barrie Hemsley, Angus Bickerton, Ryan Cook, Mark Breakspear |{{nom}} |}
==Sequel== {{main|Inferno (2016 film)}} [[Sony Pictures]] produced a [[film adaptation]] of ''[[Inferno (Dan Brown novel)|Inferno]]'', the fourth book in the ''Robert Langdon'' series, which was released on October 14, 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tom-hanks-inferno-shifts-opening-739663|title=Tom Hanks' 'Inferno' Shifts Opening to 2016|author=Gregg Kilday|work=The Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> with [[Ron Howard]] as director, [[David Koepp]] adapting the screenplay, [[Tom Hanks]] reprising his role as Robert Langdon,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/sony-dates-latest-dan-brown-movie-inferno-for-december-2015-will-come-before-lost-symbol/ |title=Tom Hanks And Ron Howard To Return For Next Dan Brown Movie ‘Inferno’; Sony Sets December 2015 Release Date |date=July 16, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 16, 2013}}</ref> and co-starring [[Felicity Jones]], [[Ben Foster]], [[Irrfan Khan]] and [[Sidse Babett Knudsen]].

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Ergot}} {{Merge to|Cryptolect|discuss=Talk:Cant (language)#Merge to Cryptolect|date=September 2017}} An '''argot''' ({{IPAc-en|lang|pron|ˈ|ɑr|ɡ|oʊ}}; from [[French language|French]] ''argot'' {{IPAc-fr|a|r|ˈ|ɡ|o}} '[[slang]]') is a [[Cant (language)|secret language]] used by various groups—e.g., schoolmates, outlaws, colleagues, gay people ([[Polari]]) among many others—to prevent outsiders from understanding their conversations. The term ''argot'' is also used to refer to the informal specialized vocabulary from a particular field of study, occupation, or hobby, in which [[word sense|sense]] it overlaps with [[jargon]]. The discipline of medicine has been referred to as having its own argot which includes abbreviations, acronyms, and "technical colloquialisms".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hukill|first=Peter B.|last2=H.|first2=A. L.|last3=Jackson|first3=James L.|date=1961|title=The Spoken Language of Medicine: Argot, Slang, Cant|jstor=453853|journal=American Speech|volume=36|issue=2|pages=145–151|doi=10.2307/453853}}</ref>
Author [[Victor Hugo]] was one of the first to research and compile terms from criminal argot.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mtholyoke.edu/courses/rschwart/hist255/popcorn/convicts2.html | title=Interesting Facts about Convicts of France in the 19th Century | author=Schwartz, Robert M. |publisher=Mt. Holyoke University}}</ref> In his 1862 novel ''[[Les Misérables]],'' he refers to that argot as both "the language of the dark" and "the language of misery."
The earliest known record of the term ''argot'' in this context was in a 1628 document. The word was probably derived from the contemporary name ''les argotiers'', given to a group of thieves at that time.<ref>Guiraud, Pierre, ''L'Argot. Que sais-je?'', Paris: PUF, 1958, p. 700</ref>
Under the strictest definition, an ''argot'' is a proper language with its own grammar and style. But such complete secret languages are rare because the speakers usually have some public language in common, on which the argot is largely based. Such argots are mainly versions of another language, with a part of its vocabulary replaced by words unknown to the larger public; ''argot'' used in this [[word sense|sense]] is [[synonym]]ous with ''[[cant (language)|cant]]''. For example, ''argot'' in this sense is used for systems such as ''[[verlan]]'' and ''[[louchébem]]'', which retain French syntax and apply transformations only to individual words (and often only to a certain subset of words, such as nouns, or semantic content words).<ref name="valdman">{{cite journal | last = Valdman | first = Albert | title = La Langue des faubourgs et des banlieues: de l'argot au français populaire | journal = The French Review | volume = 73 | issue = 6 | pages = 1179–1192 | publisher = American Association of Teachers of French | date = May 2000 | jstor = 399371|language=fr}}</ref> Such systems are examples of ''argots à clef'', or "coded argots."<ref name="valdman"/>
Specific words can go from argot into common speech or the other way. For example, modern [[French language|French]] ''[[wikt:loufoque|loufoque]]'' 'crazy, goofy', now common usage, originates in the ''[[louchébem]]'' transformation of Fr. ''[[wikt:fou|fou]]'' 'crazy'.
"Piaf" is a Parisian argot word for "bird, [[sparrow]]". It was taken up by singer [[Edith Piaf]] as her stage name.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2007/06/25/french-blues| title=French Blues| author=Judith Thurman| date=June 25, 2007| accessdate=May 5, 2015| publisher=[[The New Yorker]]}}</ref>
==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[1337 speak]] * [[Bargoens]] * [[Boontling]] * [[Caló (Chicano)]] * [[Cant (language)|Cant]] * [[Cockney rhyming slang]] * [[Fala dos arxinas]] * [[Fenya]] * [[Gayle language]] * [[Gender transposition]] * [[Grypsera]] * [[IsiNgqumo]] * [[Jargon]] * [[Joual]] * [[Klezmer-loshn]] * [[Lunfardo]] * [[Martian language]] * [[Microculture]] * [[Nadsat]] * [[Pig Latin]] * [[Polari]] * [[Rotwelsch]] * [[Lazăr Șăineanu]] * [[Shelta]] * [[Thieves' cant]] * [[Verlan]] }}
==References== <references/>
== External links == {{Wiktionary|argot}}
{{Authority control}}
[[Category:Cant languages]] [[Category:Folklore]]

page.title: Art Directors Club of New York

revision.comment: /* History */ pare unsourced promotional
revision.text:
{{POV|date=August 2015}} The '''Art Directors Club of New York''' is an organization for art directors in [[New York City]]. It was founded in 1920, and has grown as an industry group, promoting art directors' work through exhibitions and awards, including the annual DESI award for design excellence.<ref>{{Cite web|title = History|url = http://adcglobal.org/about/history/|website = ADC • Global Awards & Club|accessdate = 2016-01-02|language = en-US}}</ref>
==History== The Art Directors Club of New York (sometimes referred to as the "ADC") was founded in 1920 by Louis Pedlar and [[Earnest Elmo Calkins]]. With Fred Lamb, Calkins had organized the first advertising art exhibits in New York City in 1908,<ref>{{cite book|last=Bird|first=Harry Lewis|title=This Fascinating Advertising Business|origyear=1947|year=2008|publisher=Bobbs-Merrill, reprinted by Wildside Press|isbn=9781434475541|pages=308}}</ref> and saw a need for an organization that would “dignify the field of business art in the eyes of artists”, emphasizing his belief that “artistic excellence is vitally necessary to successful advertising”.<ref>{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.adcglobal.org/adc/history/|publisher=Art Directors Club of New York|accessdate=April 10, 2012}}</ref> By 1947, the Club's work was being credited with a gradual increase in advertising art standards throughout the United States.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bird|first=Harry Lewis|title=This Fascinating Advertising Business|origyear=1947|year=2008|publisher=Bobbs-Merrill, reprinted by Wildside Press|isbn=9781434475541|pages=309}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Graphic Design, Referenced: A Visual Guide to the Language, Applications, and History of Graphic Design|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=EwPu8I6D5y4C|publisher = Rockport Publishers|date = 2011-12-01|isbn = 9781592537426|first = Bryony Gomez|last = Palacio|first2 = Armin|last2 = Vit}}</ref>
In 1921, the club hosted their first juried exhibition with original work from over 250 contributors. The exhibition organized by Calkins and opened with an inaugural dinner on March 2, 1921. The awards that evening went to: Fred R. Cruger for black and white illustration; W.E. Hoitland for painting; and Rene Clark for poster design.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Advertising & Selling with the Advertising News|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=RtFBAQAAMAAJ|publisher = Advertising & Selling Company|date = 1921-01-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = THE WORLD OF ART:; French Paintings and American Prints|url = http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/03/20/112676937.html?pageNumber=35|website = timesmachine.nytimes.com|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref>
The Art Directors Club was restrictive in its membership during its early years. Women were not admitted until 1942. George Olden, an art director with the [[Columbia Broadcasting Company]], was the first African-American member, having been elected to the Club in 1952.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=JET|date=3 April 1952|volume= 1|issue= 23|pages=37|publisher=Johnson Publishing Co.}}</ref>
The Art Directors' Club includes art directors working in film and ''[[New media]]''.
=== Logo === The first logo was an interpretation of [[Albrecht Dürer|Albrecht Dürer’s]] signature. In 2009, ADC rebranded with the help of [[Trollbäck + Company]]. The new logo moved away from a monogram and introducing a word mark in bold hues. In 2014, they updated their logo with a monogram created by [[Sid Lee]] that references historical ADC monograms.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Brand New: New Logo and Identity for ADC by Sid Lee|url = http://www.underconsideration.com/brandnew/archives/new_logo_and_identity_for_adc_by_sid_lee.php#.VogZFpMrLMU|website = www.underconsideration.com|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = New Art Directors Club Logo Comes in Colors, Primed for ‘Pimping’|url = http://www.adweek.com/fishbowlny/new-art-directors-club-logo-comes-in-colors-primed-for-pimping/278747|website = www.adweek.com|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref>
==Awards==
=== ADC Annual Awards === Earnest Elmo Calkins organized the first juried exhibition in 1921. The ADC evolved this exhibition into its ADC Annual Awards that receives up to 11,000 entries from around the world. Several awards are given out annually to recognize industry excellence internationally. The Award for Design Excellence is known as the "DESI" award. The main categories for the award, as of 2012, are: Advertising; Design; Illustration; Integrated; Interactive; Motion; Photography; and Special Awards.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = The ADC 95th Annual Awards are here!|url = http://adcglobal.org/awards/adc-annual-awards/|website = ADC • Global Awards & Club|accessdate = 2016-01-02|language = en-US}}</ref>
=== ADC Young Guns === In 1991, ADC created the Young Guns award. ADC Young Guns are annual international awards given out to promising art directors under the age of 30. ADC GrandMasters recognizes experienced educators in art direction who have created a notable legacy in the industry.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ADC Young Guns|url = http://adcglobal.org/awards/adc-young-guns/|website = ADC • Global Awards & Club|accessdate = 2016-01-02|language = en-US}}</ref>
=== [[Art Directors Club Hall of Fame|ADC Hall of Fame]] === In 1971, ADC established their [[Art Directors Club Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]]. Those chosen for the Hall of Fame have made significant contributions throughout their lifetime to the graphic design profession.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ADC Hall of Fame|url = http://adcglobal.org/awards/hall-of-fame/|website = ADC • Global Awards & Club|accessdate = 2016-01-02|language = en-US}}</ref>
==Art Directors Annual== The Art Directors Annual is a review of the year's outstanding achievements in art direction. It has appeared yearly since 1922.
==See also== {{Portal|Visual arts|New York City}} *[[Art director]] *[[Adweek]] *[[James Jean]] *[[D&AD]] *[[New York City arts organizations]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://adcglobal.org/ Official Website]
[[Category:Art directors]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in New York City]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in New York City]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1920]] [[Category:1920 establishments in New York (state)]]

revision.text:
[[File:Jeff Koons Shankbone 2009 Vanity Fair.jpg|thumb|Jeff Koons in 2009]]'''''Banality''''' is a series of [[sculpture]]s by American artist [[Jeff Koons]]. The works were unveiled in 1988 and have become controversial for their use of copyrighted images. Several editions of the sculptures have sold at auction for millions of dollars.
==Series details==
The series consists of a number of large sculptures inspired by [[Hummel figurines]] and has been described as [[kitsch]]. They were designed to convey the emotion of "lying in the grass and taking a deep breath".<ref name="Bader">{{cite news|author=Bader, Graham|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0268/is_1_47/ai_n35574129/?tag=content;col1|title=Jeff Koons: Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago|website=ArtForum|publisher=FindArticles.com|date=September 2008|accessdate=November 6, 2011}}</ref>
When it was first unveiled, the series was simultaneously on show at three different galleries - at the [[Sonnabend Gallery]] in [[New York City]], at the Donald Young Gallery in [[Chicago]] and at the [[Galerie Max Hetzler]] in [[Cologne]]<ref>Anthony Haden-Guest: ''True Colors. The Real Life of the Art World''. Atlantic Monthly Press, New York 1998, {{ISBN|0871137259}}, p. 150.</ref> - possible because several editions of each sculpture were made. Koons promoted his works by taking out four advertisements in the major trade magazines. Each of the full-page features depicted different parts of Koons' reputed persona: #A propagator of the banal: Koons is shown alongside two pigs - published in ''[[Flash Art]]'' #A bad influence on future generations: he is in a classroom with lots of children, a blackboard contains the slogans "Exploit the Masses" and "Banality as Savior" - published in ''[[Artforum]]'' #A [[gigolo]]: he is standing in front of a boudoir-style tent - published in ''[[Flash Art]]'' #A ladies man: he is with a [[Shetland pony]] and several women in bikinis - published in ''[[Arts Magazine]]'' and ''[[Art in America]]''
The advertisements were the first time that Koons was featured in his own work, exploiting the reputation that the media and his critics had propagated.<ref name="tateetc">{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/tateetc/issue1/article5.htm|title=Lives of the Artists|author=Gingeras, Alison M.|work=Tate etc. Issue 1|date=Summer 2004|accessdate=November 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://artwelove.com/artist/-id/2099d2d1|title=Jeff Koons|publisher=artwelove.com|accessdate=November 11, 2011}}</ref>
Several sculptures from the series have been adjudged to have broken copyright laws. Koons has defended his works on numerous occasions but the courts have repeatedly rejected his claims of [[fair use]] by [[parody]].<ref name="ASOPA">{{cite web|url=http://www.asopa.com/publications/2000winter/law.htm |title=Art & LAW: Derivative Works And Copyright • Painting from Another's Photograph |author=Fergus, Mary Ann |date=Winter 2000 |accessdate=November 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111027210406/http://www.asopa.com/publications/2000winter/law.htm |archivedate=October 27, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="lawbook">{{cite book|title=Law, ethics, and the visual arts|author1=Merryman, John Henry|author2=Elsen, Albert Edward|author3=Urice, Stephen K.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_8AddekkdZ8C&pg=PA566&lpg=PA566|pages=566–567}}</ref><ref name="owe">{{cite web|url=http://www.owe.com/legalities/legalities30.htm|title=Legalities 30: Jeff Koons and Copyright Infringement|author=Kattwinkel, Linda Joy|publisher=OWE|accessdate=November 11, 2011}}</ref>
==Constituent sculptures== Most of the sculptures are made of [[porcelain]]; three editions of each were produced in addition to the artist's proof.<ref name="ADMSP">{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/admsp/sets/72157626107321283/detail/|title=Jeff Koons: Banality|work=Altos del Mar Sculpture Park|publisher=[[Flickr]]|date=March 9, 2011|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> The most notable pieces are detailed below.
===''Bear and Policeman''=== {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | image_size = 200px | title = | material = Polychromed wood<ref name="ADMSP" /> | height_metric = 215.9 | width_metric = 109.2 | length_metric = 94 | height_imperial = 85 | width_imperial = 43 | length_imperial = 37 }} A smiling brown bear wearing a striped T-shirt has his arm around a shorter policeman who is looking up at the animal.
{{quotation|"The relatively diminutive constable, a symbol of authority, contrasts comically with the bear's monstrous size and relative harmlessness. Looking helplessly up at the bear, the expression on the policeman's face holds the key to enjoying Koons' work: a temporary suspension of adulthood, a return to seeing the world through a child's perspective. Koons seems to hint that the adult world, with its explicit content, greed and shame, is worth staving off."|Angelina Krahn, Art writer for ''[[Express Milwaukee]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.expressmilwaukee.com/article-3409-in-defense-of-banality.html|title=In Defense of Banality|author=Krahn, Angelina|publisher=Express Milwaukee|date=August 30, 2008|accessdate=November 12, 2011}}</ref>}} {{Clear}}
===''Fait d'Hiver''=== {{Infobox artwork | title = | material = Porcelain<ref name="ADMSP" /> | height_metric = 49.5 | width_metric = 160 | length_metric = 80 | height_imperial = 19.5 | width_imperial = 63 | length_imperial = 31.5 }} ''Fait d'Hiver'' depicts a woman lying on her back in the snow. The upper torso and head of the woman are featured in the sculpture, her breasts exposed beneath a sparsely-knitted dress. A pig and two penguins stand near to her head, adding the kitsch element that is thematic throughout the collection. The catalogue colourfully described the work as a "Walt Disney version of an erotic fantasy ... juxtaposing a strong sexual element with the saccharine sweetness of decorative knicknacks". It went on to say that the "disturbing combination identifies a primal hunger at the heart of American consumerism".<ref name="cityreview">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecityreview.com/f01pcon1.html|title=Contemporary Art, Part I|author=Horsley, Carter B.|publisher=The City Review|date=November 12, 2001|accessdate=November 11, 2011}}</ref>
Koons based the design of the woman on a photograph of porn actress [[Ilona Staller]] that featured in ''[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]''.<ref name="cityreview" /> He had not met Staller at the time but went on to have a very public relationship with her, using her as a muse for many subsequent works.<ref name="tateetc" />
In November 2001 an edition of the sculpture was auctioned by [[Phillips de Pury & Company]] with an estimate of up to US$2.5 million but it failed to sell.<ref name="cityreview" /> Several years later, on November 13, 2007, [[Christie's]] auctioned the artist's proof with a final sale price of US$4.3 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/print_sale.aspx?saleid=21391|title=Post-War And Contemporary Art Evening Sale|date=November 13, 2007|accessdate=November 11, 2011|publisher=[[Christie's]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecityreview.com/f07ccon1.html|title=Post War and Contemporary Art|author=Leight, Michele|publisher=The City Review|date=November 13, 2007|accessdate=November 11, 2011}}</ref> In 2018 a French court found that Koons' sculpture had plagiarised a 1985 advertisement for {{ill|Naf Naf|fr}}, a women's clothing retailer. Damages and costs were awarded against Koons but the sculpture was not seized.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shaw |first1=Andy |title=Copyright case brought by Naf Naf creative director against Jeff Koons finally comes to court |url=https://www.theartnewspaper.com/news/copyright-case-brought-by-naf-naf-creative-director-against-jeff-koons-finally-comes-to-court |work=www.theartnewspaper.com |date=26 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Sansom |first1=Anna |title=Jeff Koons loses French lawsuit over ‘slavish copy’ of Naf Naf advert |url=https://www.theartnewspaper.com/news/jeff-koons-loses-french-lawsuit-over-slavish-copy-of-naf-naf-advert |work=www.theartnewspaper.com |date=9 November 2018}}</ref>
===''Michael Jackson and Bubbles''=== {{see also|Michael Jackson and Bubbles}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | image_size = 200px | title = | material = Porcelain<ref name="ADMSP" /> | height_metric = 106.7 | width_metric = 179.1 | length_metric = 82.6 | height_imperial = 42 | width_imperial = 70.5 | length_imperial = 32.5 }}
In 1988, [[Jeff Koons]] made three identical porcelain sculptures of Bubbles and Jackson.<ref name="BennettTelegraph">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/1330570/Mystery-buyer-pays-4m-for-golden-vision-of-Jackson-and-his-chimp.html|title=Mystery buyer pays £4m for golden vision of Jackson and his chimp|last=Bennett|first=Will|date=June 5, 2001|work=The Daily Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph Media Group|accessdate=April 2, 2009|location=London}}</ref> At the time, each sculpture was said to be worth $250,000.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/06/nyregion/no-walking-just-watering-for-this-puppy.html|title=No Walking, Just Watering for This Puppy|last=Dewan|first=Shaila K.|date=June 6, 2000|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=April 2, 2009}}</ref> Koons once said of the pop star, "If I could be one other living person, it would probably be Michael Jackson."<ref name="BennettTelegraph" /> The art piece went on to become one of Koons' best known works.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Art foundry flounders after sculptor's suit|date=March 27, 1998|work=[[Central Penn Business Journal]]|publisher=Journal Publications, Inc }}</ref> The figure shows Jackson and the chimpanzee wearing gold military-style suits.<ref name="BennettTelegraph" /> In 2001, one of the figures was put up for auction and was expected to fetch between $3 million and $4 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2001/05/23/0523feat.html|title=Trouble Ahead For Art Market|last=Rohleder|first=Anna|work=[[Forbes]]|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=April 2, 2009}}</ref> The figure sold to an anonymous telephone bidder for $5.6 million.<ref name="BennettTelegraph" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5sMDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA35&dq=%22michael+jackson%22+bubbles+chimpanzee&cd=43#v=onepage&q=%22michael%20jackson%22%20bubbles%20chimpanzee&f=false|title=Multimillion-dollar sculpture|date=June 4, 2001|work=Jet|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|accessdate=August 21, 2009}}</ref> The sale was a record for a work by Koons.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/20/style/that-cool-that-suit-sotheby-s-007.html?sec=&spon=&pagewanted=2|title=That Cool, That Suit: Sotheby's 007|last=Mason|first=Christopher|date=May 20, 2001|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=April 2, 2009}}</ref>
===''Pink Panther''=== {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | image_size = 200px | title = | material = Porcelain<ref name="ADMSP" /> | height_metric = 104.1 | width_metric = 52.1 | length_metric = 48.3 | height_imperial = 41 | width_imperial = 20.5 | length_imperial = 19 }}
''Pink Panther'' is a 41-inch tall porcelain sculpture featuring [[Jayne Mansfield]] holding the cartoon character [[Pink Panther (character)|Pink Panther]]. Mansfield is sculpted from the waist up and is partly clothed, her breasts being exposed;<ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F05EEDF173EF932A25750C0A9679D8B63&pagewanted=all|title=INSIDE ART; MoMA to Acquire Cy Twombly Works|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|author=Vogel, Carol|date=March 11, 2011|accessdate=November 27, 2011}}</ref> her right hand covers her nearly-exposed breast. The Pink Panther is shown in full, his chin over the left shoulder of Mansfield. [[Robert Storr (art academic)|Robert Storr]], curator of the Department of Painting and Sculpture at the [[Museum of Modern Art]], commented on the piece: "His mating of Jayne Mansfield and the eponymous cartoon character in Pink Panther is a thoroughly enjoyable send-up of heterosexual rapture and celebrity romance."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/1997/dannheisser/commentary.html#koons|title=Commentary: Jeff Koons|author=Storr, Robert|publisher=[[Museum of Modern Art]], New York|accessdate=November 6, 2011}}</ref> Koons' himself states that the piece was intended to represent the Pink Panther as a female masturbation aid. His depiction of the character caused legal issues and Koons was sued for copyright infringement, eventually settling out of court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitalcommons.wcl.american.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1112&context=jgspl|title=Symposium: My Fair Ladies: Sex, Gender, and Fair Use in Copyright|author=[[Tushnet, Rebecca]]|work=American University Journal of Gender, Social Policy & the Law. 15, no. 2 (2007): 273-303|page=11|publisher=The Berkeley Electronic Press|year=2007|accessdate=November 27, 2011}}</ref>
One edition of ''Pink Panther'' was sold at [[Sotheby's]] in May 2011 with a complementary description in the catalogue entry: {{quotation|"Representing the highest tier of Jeff Koons' artistic achievement, ''Pink Panther'' is immediately identifiable as a masterpiece not only of the artist's historic canon, but also of the epoch of recent Contemporary Art. It conflates the classic themes that define the artist's output—materiality and artificiality, eroticism and naivety, popular culture and rarefied elitism—and is the model expression of one of the most innovative and influential artists of our times."|Sotheby's catalogue entry about ''Pink Panther''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arthistorynews.com/articles/210_Superlativeitis|title=Superlative-itis|publisher=Art History News|author=Grosvenor, Bendor|date=April 20, 2011|accessdate=November 6, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/12/us-auction-koons-idUSTRE72B00W20110312|title=Koons sculpture could fetch $30 million at auction|author=Michaud, Chris|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=March 12, 2011|accessdate=November 6, 2011}}</ref>}}
On May 10, 2011, it sold significantly below the US$20–30 million expected price, reaching US$16,882,500.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/08/13/2011-auction-round-up-who_n_924959.html|title=2011 Auction Round-Up: Who's on Top and Who Flopped (PHOTOS, VIDEO)|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=August 13, 2011|accessdate=November 6, 2011|first=Sydney|last=Edelist}}</ref>
===''Saint John the Baptist''=== {{Infobox artwork | title = | material = Porcelain<ref name="ADMSP" /> | height_metric = 142.2 | width_metric = 73.7 | length_metric = 43.2 | height_imperial = 56 | width_imperial = 29 | length_imperial = 17 }} Inspired by [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s painting, ''[[St. John the Baptist (Leonardo)|St. John the Baptist]]'', Koons' sculpture was made in the same pose but he also added a pig and a bird into the saint's arms. His outstretched arm points to a cross.<ref name="Jones">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2009/jun/30/jeff-koons-exhibition-serpentine|title=Jeff Koons: Not just the king of kitsch|date=June 30, 2009|author=Jones, Jonathan|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=November 6, 2011|location=London}}</ref><ref name="Dorsey">{{cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1993-04-12/features/1993102072_1_jeff-koons-shameless-self-promoter-porcelain|title=Artist Jeff Koons paints a portrait of sincerity and self-promotion|date=April 12, 1993|author=Dorsey, John|publisher=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|accessdate=November 6, 2011}}</ref> It has been described as "an insouciant yet sinister conflation of the sacred and the profane".<ref name="Hackett">{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/ae/article/Restorer-rescues-Saint-John-after-Koons-1142488.php|title=Restorer rescues 'Saint John' after Koons' sculpture is damaged|author=Hackett, Regina|publisher=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|date=April 18, 2004|accessdate=November 6, 2011}}</ref>
One edition of the sculpture was set to go on show at the Wright Exhibition Space in [[Seattle]] in February 2004, but it was discovered to have a sizeable crack along the arm. Bought in 1991 for US$150,000, the damage is expected to have reduced the resale price of the piece, though none of the editions have been sold at auction since. Patricia Leavengood, a sculpture conservation specialist, partly restored the damage and reduced the visibility of the crack. She noted, however, that "When it cracked, part of it slid forward and can't be moved back into place ... Porcelain wasn't meant to exist at this size. My primary task is to stabilize the piece, and that I can do."<ref name="Hackett" />
===''String of Puppies''=== {{Infobox artwork | title = | material = Porcelain<ref name="ADMSP" /> | height_metric = 106.7 | width_metric = 157.5 | length_metric = 94 | height_imperial = 42 | width_imperial = 62 | length_imperial = 37 }} ''String of Puppies'' is a porcelain sculpture depicting a man and a woman sat on a bench holding eight blue puppies. The inspiration came from a photograph by [[Art Rogers]] entitled ''Puppies''. Koons found the picture on a postcard and, when he gave it to his assistants with instructions on how to model the sculpture, he asked that as much detail be copied as possible. He requested a few changes to the original, asking for the puppies to be blue with exaggerated noses, and for flowers to be added to the hair of the man and woman. The three editions of the sculpture were sold for a total of $367,000.<ref name="ASOPA" /><ref name="lawbook" /><ref name="rogers">{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=9102865469766650757&q=rogers+v.+koons&hl=en&as_sdt=2,5|title=Rogers v. Koons, 960 F. 2d 301 - Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit 1992|date=April 2, 1992|accessdate=November 11, 2011}}</ref>
Upon discovering that his picture had been copied, [[Rogers v. Koons|Rogers sued Koons]] and the Sonnabend Gallery for [[copyright infringement]]. Koons admitted to having copied the image intentionally and, in 1992, the court found "[[substantial similarity]]" between the two works and that Koons acted in a "willful and egregious" manner. They rejected his parody argument and awarded a significant settlement to Rogers.<ref name="ASOPA" /><ref name="rogers" />
===''Ushering in Banality''=== {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | image_size = 200px | title = | material = Polychromed wood<ref name="ADMSP" /> | height_metric = 96.5 | width_metric = 157.5 | length_metric = 76.2 | height_imperial = 38 | width_imperial = 62 | length_imperial = 30 }} A pig with a green ribbon is being pushed by two young angels (alongside it) with a young boy dressed in a tracksuit behind it.<ref name="Jones" /> ''Ushering in Banality'' was ruled to have "deliberately and exactly copied" a photograph by Barbara Campbell. Koons had instructed his Italian studio to replicate Campbell's ''Boys with Pig'' using it as a model for the design.<ref name="lawbook" />
At a Sotheby's auction in November 2001 one of the three editions of ''Ushering in Banality'' sold for US$1,875,750.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecityreview.com/f01scon1.html|title=Contemporary Art|author=Horsley, Carter B.|publisher=The City Review|date=November 12, 2001|accessdate=November 11, 2011}}</ref>
===''Wild Boy and Puppy''=== {{Infobox artwork | title = | material = Porcelain<ref name="ADMSP" /> | height_metric = 96.5 | width_metric = 100.3 | length_metric = 59.7 | height_imperial = 38 | width_imperial = 39.5 | length_imperial = 23.5 }} ''Wild Boy and Puppy'' is a porcelain sculpture featuring a yellow cartoon dog, a "wild boy" with red spiky hair, and a bumblebee in a basket. The cartoon dog is a clear replica of [[Odie]] from the ''[[Garfield]]'' comic strip by [[Jim Davis (cartoonist)|Jim Davis]] with only minimal changes. In 1993, [[United Feature Syndicate, Inc.]] sued Koons for his unsanctioned use of Odie, successfully arguing that he had breached copyright law. Koons had defended himself in other cases using the parody argument but could not do so here—he testified to being unaware of the source of the character and therefore could not have directed the parody at the comic.<ref name="owe" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=4976164098054376167|title=United Feature Syndicate, Inc. v. Koons, 817 F. Supp. 370 - Dist. Court, SD|date=March 24, 1993|accessdate=November 11, 2011}}</ref>
One edition of the sculpture sold in November 2004 for US$1.5 million, significantly higher than its US$400,000 estimate.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/12/arts/12auction.html|title=Momentum in Art Auctions Continues to the End|author=Vogel, Carol|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=November 12, 2004|accessdate=November 12, 2011}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of most expensive sculptures]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Jeff Koons}}
[[Category:Sculptures by Jeff Koons]] [[Category:Sculptures depicting John the Baptist]] [[Category:Sculpture series]] [[Category:Dogs in art]] [[Category:Pigs in art]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Horses in art]]
