revision.text:
{{multiple image | align = right | total_width = 320
| image1 = Hammer and sickle red on transparent.svg | width1 = 414| height1 = 414 | alt1 = | caption1 =
| image2 = Red star.svg | width2 = 1235| height2 = 1175 | alt2 = | caption2 =
| footer = Symbols commonly associated with communism, the [[hammer and sickle]] and [[red star]] }} '''Bans on [[Communist symbol]]s''' were introduced or suggested in a number of countries as part of their policies of [[decommunization]].<ref name=runei>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/bans-on-communist-symbols-spread-through-russia-neighbors/1488856.html|title=Communist Symbol Ban Spreads in Europe|first=James|last=Brooke|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref>
==By country== [[File:Madrid may day375.jpg|thumb|The plain [[Red flag (politics)|red flag]] is often used at socialist or communist rallies, especially on [[International Workers' Day]]]] [[File:Communist symbols in world.png|center|thumb|700px| {{legend|#9BB7C8|States where communist symbols are banned}} {{legend|#C89B9B|States where communist symbols were formerly banned}} {{legend|#67DC61|States where some communist symbols are banned with the resolution of communist symbols in general}}]] ===Indonesia=== [[File:Anti PKI Literature.jpg|thumb|Anti-communist propaganda leaflets and literature, blaming the [[Indonesian Communist Party]] for being the actor of [[30 September Movement]] ]] Communism alongside [[Marxism-Leninism]] were officially banned in [[Indonesia]] following the aftermath of [[30 September Movement|30 September coup attempt]] and the subsequent [[Indonesian mass killings of 1965-1966|anti-communist killings]], by adoption of ''TAP MPRS'' no. 25/1966 in 1966 and ''Undang Undang'' no. 27/1999 in 1999, which are still in force. The law does not explicitly declare a ban on symbols of Communism, but [[Indonesian police]] frequently use the law to arrest people displaying it.<ref>[http://news.detik.com/berita/3206373/ini-penjelasan-kapolri-soal-lambang-palu-arit-yang-dilarang-di-indonesia Police chief explanation on banned hammer and sickle symbol in Indonesia] (in Indonesian)</ref> Some of its violators were people with no knowledge of symbols of Communism, in which cases the authorities frequently freed them with only minor punishment or small fine applied.<ref>[http://regional.kompas.com/read/2016/07/10/19380351/pakai.kaus.bergambar.palu.arit.seorang.petani.ditangkap.polisi Farmer arrested after wearing shirt with hammer and sickle] (in Indonesian)</ref> However, displaying such symbols in an attempt to intentionally propagate Communist or Marxist-Leninist ideas are an extremely severe offence, even considered as [[treason]] against the country and could be punished by up to 20 years of prison.<ref>[http://m.hukumonline.com/pusatdata/detail/lt50768a41ad5ab/node/657/tap-mprs-no-xxv_mprs_1966-tahun-1966-pembubaran-partai-komunis-indonesia,-pernyataan-sebagai-organisasi-terlarang-diseluruh-wilayah-negara-republik-indonesia-bagi-partai-komunis-indonesia-dan-larangan-setiap-kegiatan-untuk-menyebarkan-atau-mengembangkan-faham-atau-ajaran-komunis_marxisme-leninisme Explanations on banning communism and Marxism-Leninism in Indonesia] (in Indonesian)</ref><ref>[http://www.wirantaprawira.de/law/criminal/security/index.html Undang Undang no.27/1999, laws on Communism and Marxism-Leninism] (Indonesian)</ref> This makes Indonesia a country with a very strict [[Anti-communism|anti-communist]] policy compared to other countries that also practiced anti-communism.
Other [[socialist]] and [[left-wing]] related symbols, while not officially prohibited by law (as [[democratic socialism]] itself remained acceptable in the country) are still widely condemned by the Indonesian people and considered as being closely related to Communism in general. These include the [[red star]], the [[socialist heraldry]], the [[red flag (politics)|red flag]], and anthems or slogans such as ''[[The Internationale]]'' and "[[Workers of the world, unite!]]". Despite this, ''The Internationale'' was still remained in use during [[International Labour Day]].
In addition, since the [[Transition to the New Order|New Order regime]] was established in 1967, the [[hammer and sickle]] has become [[social stigma|stigmatized]] in the country, which itself is very similar to how [[Nazi symbolism]] is treated in the West in general. As such, displaying the symbol in public, even without any political intentions, is still regarded as highly offensive. Because of this, Indonesians are usually prone to report those who displayed the symbol in public to the authorities.
Indonesia is the first country in the world to introduce a ban on Communist symbols, not including the [[Axis powers|Axis countries]] during [[World War II]].
In April 2017, Indonesian police detained a [[Malaysians|Malaysian]] tourist at a hotel in [[Mataram (city)|Mataram]] for wearing a T-shirt with an image of the hammer and sickle symbol. The tourist was not aware that Communist symbols were banned in Indonesia. The police seized the T-shirt and released the tourist after giving him a warning.<ref name="Malaysian detained in Indonesia for wearing T-shirt with communist symbol">{{cite|title = Malaysian detained in Indonesia for wearing T-shirt with communist symbol|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysian-detained-in-indonesia-for-wearing-t-shirt-with-communist-symbol|publisher = The Straits Times|date = 14 April 2017|accessdate = 17 May 2017}}</ref>
In May 2018, a Russian tourist was confronted by locals and reported to the police in [[Bali]] for flying a Soviet [[Banner of Victory]] to commemorate [[Victory Day]].
===United States=== During the [[First Red Scare|Red Scare of 1919–20]] in the [[United States]], many states passed laws forbidding the display of [[red flag (politics)|red flag]]s, including [[Minnesota]], [[South Dakota]], [[Oklahoma]],<ref>Zechariah Chafee, Jr., ''Freedom of Speech'' (NY: Harcourt, Brace and Howe, 1920), 180ff., Appendix V</ref> and [[California]]. In ''[[Stromberg v. California]]'', the United States Supreme Court held that such laws are unconstitutional.<ref>''Stromberg v. California'', 283 U.S. 359 (1931).</ref>
===Moldova=== In 2009, such a ban was proposed in [[Moldova]] by parliamentarian Oleg Serebryan,<ref name=pola/> and the law came into effect in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/moldova-ban-on-use-of-communist-symbols/|title=Moldova: Ban on Use of Communist Symbols - Global Legal Monitor|date=28 November 2012|website=www.loc.gov|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> The Constitutional Court of Moldova found it unconstitutional.<ref name=khpg/>
=== Ukraine === In 2015 the Verkhovna Rada passed a [[Ukrainian decommunization laws|law banning communist and nazi symbols]]. Earlier, in 2012, the city of [[Lviv]] in [[Western Ukraine]] banned the public display of Communist symbols.<ref name="runei" /> On December 2015, all communist parties were officially banned in Ukraine.
=== Estonia === On November 30, 2006, [[Estonia]]n government signed the draft law to ban politically motivated display of Soviet and Nazi symbols in public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/1073110.html|title=Estonia Proposes Ban On Soviet, Nazi Symbols|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> On January 24, 2007 it was passed in the first reading by the parliament. The bill specifies those symbols: the flags, coats of arms, other attributes, and slogans of the USSR, the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Germany's [[Nazi Party]], and its SS organization.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=32427&no_cache=1#.VrGgU_krKM8 "Moscow stung by Estonian ban on totalitarianism's symbols"], ''Eurasia Daily Monitor'', Vol. 4, Issue 19, 2007</ref> However, it eventually failed the parliamentary committee on the grounds of [[freedom of speech]]. {{citation needed|date=February 2016}}
=== Lithuania === [[Lithuania]] banned Soviet and Nazi symbols in 2008 (Article 188<sup>18</sup> of the Code of Administrative Offences) under the threat of a fine.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/europe/7459976.stm | work=BBC News | title=Lithuanian ban on Soviet symbols | date=2008-06-17}}</ref> Article 5 of the Law on Meetings prohibits meetings involving Nazist and Soviet imagery.<ref>Joint amicus curiae brief, p. 11</ref> As of 2015, the laws were in effect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baltictimes.com/audi_featuring_soviet_symbols_banned_from_entering_lithuania/|title=Audi featuring Soviet symbols banned from entering Lithuania|website=www.baltictimes.com|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref>
=== Latvia === In June 2014, the [[Latvia]]n parliament approved a ban on the display of Soviet and Nazi symbols at all public events. The ban involves flags, anthems, uniforms, Nazi ''[[hakenkreuz]]'' and the Soviet [[hammer and sickle]].<ref name="Latvia Bans Soviet, Nazi Symbols">{{citation|title = Latvia Bans Soviet, Nazi Symbols|url = http://en.ria.ru/russia/20130621/181788657/Latvia-Bans-Soviet-Nazi-Symbols.html|publisher = RIA Novosti|date = 21 Jun 2013|accessdate = 14 Sep 2014}}</ref>
=== Georgia === In [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] a ban was introduced in 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/georgia-ban-on-soviet-symbols-proposed/|title=Georgia: Ban on Soviet Symbols Proposed - Global Legal Monitor|date=8 December 2010|website=www.loc.gov|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> but it failed to define the applicable sanctions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dfwatch.net/georgia-to-enforce-ban-on-communist-symbols-44753-23804|title=Georgia to enforce ban on communist symbols|date=31 October 2013|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> In 2014, there was a proposal to amend the ban,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/av/world-europe-27272993/communist-symbols-to-be-banned-in-georgia|title=Communist symbols to be banned in Georgia|date=4 May 2014|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref> however as of 2015, the law remained inactive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gcssi.org/wp2/?p=5618|title="Decommunization of Georgia: causes, excuses and permanent interference."|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref>
===Czech Republic=== In 1991, in [[Czechoslovakia]] the criminal code was amended with w § 260 which banned propaganda of movements which restricted human rights and freedoms, citing Nazism and Communism. Later the specific mentions of these were removed citing their lack of clear legal definition. However the law itself was recognized as constitutional.<ref name=khpg/><ref>[http://www.legislationline.org/documents/id/17873 "Joint amicus curiae brief for the Constitutional Court of Moldova on the compatibility with European standards"], p. 8</ref> However, in 2005, there was a petition in the [[Czech Republic]] to ban the promotion of Communism and in 2007, there was a proposed amendment to the law to ban Communist symbols. Both attempts failed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expats.cz/prague/article/politics/communists-in-czech-politics/|title=Communists in Czech Politics|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> <ref>Joint amicus curiae brief, p. 13</ref>
=== Poland === In 2009, in [[Poland]]<ref name=pola>{{cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/politics/poland-bans-communist-symbols/|title=New Polish law equates Communist and Nazi symbols|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> § 2 to 4 were added to Article 256, which ban "fascist, communist or other totalitarian symbols" unless used "as part of artistic, educational, collecting or academic activity." On July 19, 2011, the [[Constitutional Tribunal of Poland]] found this ban unconstitutional due to the violation of [[freedom of expression]].<ref>Joint amicus curiae brief, p. 12</ref> In June 2017, Poland updated its "[[decommunization]]" legislation to include Soviet propaganda monuments, prompting negative reactions from the Russian government.<ref name="Russia warns Poland not to touch Soviet WW2 memorials">{{cite|title = Russia warns Poland not to touch Soviet WW2 memorials|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-40775355|publisher = BBC News|date = 31 July 2017|accessdate = 2 August 2017}}</ref>
=== Hungary === [[Hungary]] had a law (Article 269/B of the Criminal Code (2000)) that banned the use of symbols of fascist and communist dictatorships.<ref name=khpg>{{cite web|url=http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1430564974|title=Analysis of the Law on Prohibiting Communist Symbols - Human Rights in Ukraine|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref><ref>Hungarian Criminal Code 269 / B. § 1993</ref> The same year the Constitutional Court upheld the law when it was challenged, claiming that the involved restriction of the [[freedom of expression]] was justified.<ref>Joint amicus curiae brief, p. 9</ref> In July 2008 the [[European Court of Human Rights]] considered the challenge of Attila Vajnai who was charged with a misdemeanor for use of the [[red star]] and declared the Hungarian law to be in violation of the freedom of expression. The Court recognized the gross violations by the Nazi and Communist regimes; however, it noted that modern Hungary is a stable democracy with negligible chance of dictatorship, therefore restrictions on the freedom of expression have no justification in the country in the form of a "clear, pressing and specific social need".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politics.hu/20080709/european-court-overturns-hungarian-prohibition-on-communist-star/|title=European court overturns Hungarian prohibition on "communist" star|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> Eventually the law was annulled in 2013 by the Constitutional Court, citing the lack of precise definition and the European Court of Human Rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/emergingeurope/2013/02/20/hungary-court-annuls-ban-on-fascist-communist-symbols/|title=Hungary Court Annuls Ban on Fascist, Communist Symbols|first=Veronika|last=Gulyas|date=20 February 2013|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> In March 2017, Prime Minister [[Viktor Orbán]] introduced a draft law that outlaws merchandise featuring symbols like the Nazi swastika or the communist five-pointed red star, including the one used by the Dutch brewing company [[Heineken International|Heineken]].<ref name="Hungary threatens to ban Heineken's red star as 'communist'">{{cite|title = Hungary threatens to ban Heineken's red star as 'communist'|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/24/hungary-threatens-to-ban-heineken-star-logo-as-communist|publisher = The Guardian|date = 24 March 2017|accessdate = 29 March 2017}}</ref>
=== Romania === [[Romania]]n Law 51/1991, Art.3 considers the following as threats to national security: "initiating, organizing, committing or supporting in any way totalitarian or extremist actions of a communist, fascist, legionary or of any other racist, antisemitic, revisionist, separatist nature that can endanger in any way the unity and territorial integrity of Romania, and inciting actions that can endanger the rule of law". However, symbols are not mentioned in the Law.
=== Bulgaria === In [[Bulgaria]], lawmakers have voted on 24 November 2016 to make the public display of communist symbols illegal. The law, known as the "Criminal Nature of the Communist Regime", requires that signs and items created during the Communist regime glorifying the former Communist party and its leaders be removed from public places. A ban is introduced on putting such signs in public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bta.bg/en/c/DF/id/1466614|title=Parliament Passes Amendments to Act Declaring the Criminal Nature of the Communist Regime in Bulgaria|publisher=|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.euscoop.com/en/2017/9/7/protests-for-removal-of-soviet-monument|title=New protests for the removal of the statue of the Soviet Army in Sofia|publisher=|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.calvertjournal.com/news/show/7304/bulgaria-bans-public-display-of-communist-symbols|title=Bulgaria bans public display of communist symbols|publisher=|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref>
=== Mongolia === In 2012, [[Mongolia]] has removed the last statue of [[Vladimir Lenin]] in its capital, [[Ulaanbaatar]]. No law on decommunization in the country will be planned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-19940437|title=Mongolian capital removes Lenin|date=14 October 2012|publisher=|accessdate=7 October 2018|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
===Croatia=== The use of fascist and communist symbols is currently under review in [[Croatia]], one of the discussions being the banning of the [[red star]], a symbol used by the [[Yugoslav People's Army]] during the [[Croatian War of Independence]].<ref name="Croatia to Review Use of Fascist, Communist Symbols">{{cite|title = Croatia to Review Use of Fascist, Communist Symbols|url = http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/croatian-govt-forms-dealing-with-past-council-03-02-2017|publisher = Balkan Insight|author = Sven Milekic|date = 2 March 2017|accessdate = 8 March 2017}}</ref>
===Albania=== [[Albania]]'s Institute for Communist Crimes (ICC) proposed a ban on [[Cinema of Albania|communist-era films]], sparking negative reactions from the public.<ref name="Proposed Ban on Albanian Communist Films Sparks Backlash">{{cite|title = Proposed Ban on Albanian Communist Films Sparks Backlash|url = http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/initiative-to-ban-albanian-communist-movies-couse-backlash-03-15-2017#sthash.CjsDtU7P.dpuf|publisher = Balkan Insight|author = Fatjona Mejdini|date = 16 March 2017|accessdate = 1 April 2017}}</ref>
===Germany=== The [[Flag of East Germany]] was outlawed as an unconstitutional and criminal symbol in West Germany and West Berlin, where it was referred to as the {{lang|de|Spalterflagge}} (secessionist flag) until the late 1960s, when the ban was lifted.
===South Korea=== Similarly, the [[flag of North Korea]] is prohibited in [[South Korea]] as an unconstitutional symbol though some exceptions exist.<ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/us-games-asian-northkorea-flag/seoul-reminds-citizens-of-north-korea-flag-ban-idUSKBN0H708Z20140912</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://aroundtherings.com/site/A__62654/Title__South-Korea-Makes-Olympic-Exception-for-North-Korean-Flag/292/Articles|title=South Korea Makes Olympic Exception for North Korean Flag|website=aroundtherings.com|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref>
==European Union== In January 2005, [[Vytautas Landsbergis]], backed by Member of the [[European Parliament]] from Hungary, [[Jozsef Szajer]], urged a ban on the Communist symbols in the [[European Union]], in addition to [[Nazi symbols]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baltictimes.com/news/articles/11858/|title=Estonian MEP supports ban of communist symbols|website=www.baltictimes.com|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> In February 2005, the [[European Commission]] rejected calls for a proposed Europe-wide ban on Nazi symbols to be extended to cover Communist Party symbols as well. However this rejection did not rule out the individual states having their own laws in this respect.<ref>JOINT AMICUS CURIAE BRIEF, p. 24</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4248425.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Europe - EU rejects Communist symbol ban|website=news.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> In December 2013, a group of MEPs including Landsbergis addressed a letter to the President of the European Parliament, in which they requested a ban of symbols of totalitarian regimes.
==See also== * [[Denazification]] * [[Post-World War II legality of Nazi flags|Bans on Nazi symbols]] * [[Strafgesetzbuch section 86a]] * [[Decommunization]] * [[Red star#Legal status]] * [[Hammer and sickle#Legal status]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Decommunization]] [[Category:Symbols of communism]] [[Category:Iconoclasm]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/47.192.49.110|47.192.49.110]] ([[User talk:47.192.49.110|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.4.2)
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2008}} {{Pan-African|right}} '''Black orientalism''' is an intellectual and cultural movement found primarily within [[African-American]] circles. While similar to the general movement of [[Orientalism]] in its negative outlook upon [[Western Asia]]n - especially Arab - culture and religion, it differs in both its emphasis upon the role of the [[Arab slave trade]] and the [[Coolie]] slave trade in the historic dialogue between [[sub-Saharan Africa]] and the [[Arab world|Arab]] - and greater [[Muslim world|Muslim]] - world, as well as a lack of colonial promotion over the Middle East region as was promoted by European orientalism in the same region. The term "black orientalism" was first used by Kenyan academic [[Ali Mazrui]] in his critique of [[Henry Louis Gates, Jr.]]'s documentary ''Wonders of the African World''. Supporters of this movement include writers such as [[Chinweizu Ibekwe|Chinweizu]]. ==Black orientalism and Afrocentrism== Black orientalism, prior to its appropriation by religious Christian black nationalists, was formulated within the context of [[Afrocentrism]]; Jackson later wrote that it was [[Molefi Kete Asante]] who formed the base of its black orientalism:
Adoption of Islam is as contradictory to the [[African diaspora|Diasporan]] Afrocentricity as [[Christianity]] has been. Christianity has been dealt with admirably by other writers, notably [[Maulana Karenga|Karenga]]; but [[Islam]] within the African- American community ha [sic] yet to come under Afrocentric scrutiny. Understand that this oversight is due more to a sympathetic audience than it is to the perfection of Islam for African-Americans. While the [[Nation of Islam]] under the leadership of [[Elijah Muhammad]] was a transitional nationalist movement, the present emphasis of [[Islam in the United States|Islam in America]] is more cultural and religious. --Molefi Kete Asante, ''Afrocentricity'' (1988)
==Reaction by Muslim writers== The term "black orientalism" was first used by Kenyan academic [[Ali Mazrui]] in his Internet critique of [[Henry Louis Gates, Jr.]]'s documentary ''Wonders of the African World''. Mazrui had criticized the film for having markedly deemphasized the history of Islam in Africa, to the point where the history of Nigeria - half of whose population is Muslim - was all but absent from the general coverage by the documentary.[http://www.h-net.org/~africa/sources/mazruigates2.htm ''Black Orientalism? Further Reflections on "Wonders of the African World" by Henry Louis Gates, Jr.''], by Ali Mazrui, November 11, 1999. The term was later used by [[Sherman Jackson]] in an article for ''[[Islamica Magazine]]'', which criticized Black orientalism as a backlash from the oft-conservative Christian [[African studies]] scholars who have seen [[African American Muslims|Black Islam]] as a political threat of sorts. The article was later included in his book ''Islam and the Blackamerican''. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060709030803/http://www.islamicamagazine.com/content/view/27/109/ "Black Orientalism: Its Genesis, Aims, and Significance for American Islam", ''Islamica''.] * [http://igcs.binghamton.edu/igcs_site/dirton2.htm Ali Mazrui - ''Wonders of Black Orientalism''] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061119170824/http://izzymo.wordpress.com/2006/05/19/be-careful-of-the-company-you-keep/ ''Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Black Orientalism''] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070713043513/http://www.africaresource.com/war/vol1.2/vol1.2a/maguire.html Thomas E. R. Maguire, ''The Islamic Simulacrum in Henry Louis Gates, Jr.'s Into Africa''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Orientalism}} [[Category:Islam in the United States]] [[Category:African-American society]] [[Category:African diaspora]] [[Category:African-American history]] [[Category:African and Black nationalism]] [[Category:Orientalism]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Redirect|DUMBO|the 1941 animated film|Dumbo}} {{Infobox settlement <!-- Basic info --> |name = DUMBO |official_name = |other_name = Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass |nickname = |settlement_type = [[Neighborhoods of Brooklyn|Neighborhood of Brooklyn]] |motto = <!-- images and maps --> |image_skyline = DUMBO Brooklyn, as seen from the viewing gallery of One World Trade Center.jpg |imagesize = 300px |image_caption = View of Dumbo from [[One World Trade Center]], framed by the [[Brooklyn Bridge]] (bottom right) and [[Manhattan Bridge]] (center left) | image_map = {{maplink|frame=y|plain=yes|frame-align=center|frame-lat=40.705|frame-long=-73.975|zoom=9|type=point|coord={{coord|40.703|-73.990}}}} | map_alt = | map_caption = Location in New York City |image_map1 = |mapsize1 = |map_caption1 = |coordinates = {{coord|40.703|-73.990|type:city_region:US_dim:1000|display=inline,title}} | coor_pinpoint = | coordinates_footnotes = |pushpin_map = USA New York City#USA New York#USA |pushpin_label_position = |pushpin_map_caption = Location |pushpin_mapsize = <!-- location ------------------> | subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] | subdivision_name = {{flag|United States}} | subdivision_type1 = [[U.S. state|State]] | subdivision_name1 = {{flag|New York}} | subdivision_type2 = [[City]] | subdivision_name2 = {{flag|New York City}} | subdivision_type3 = [[Borough (New York City)|Borough]] | subdivision_name3 ={{Flagicon image|Flag of Brooklyn, New York.png|size=23px}} [[Brooklyn]]
<!-- Area --> |unit_pref = Imperial |area_footnotes = |area_total_sq_mi =0.050 |population_as_of = [[United States Census, 2010|2010]] |population_footnotes = |population_total = 1,139 |population_note = |population_density_km2 = auto
<!-- Area/postal codes & others --> |postal_code_type = [[Zip code|ZIP Codes]] |postal_code = 11201 |area_code = [[Area codes 718, 347, and 929|718, 347, 929]], and [[Area code 917|917]] |blank_name = [[Household income in the United States|Median household income]] |blank_info = $171,842<ref name="Detailed Profile">{{cite web |title=Dumbo neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York (NY), 11201 detailed profile |url=http://www.city-data.com/neighborhood/Dumbo-Brooklyn-NY.html |work=City-Data.com |publisher=Urban Mapping, Inc. |accessdate=September 6, 2015}}</ref> |website = |footnotes = {{Infobox NRHP | name = DUMBO Industrial District | embed = yes | nrhp_type = hd | nocat = yes | image = Plymouthst.JPG | caption = Plymouth Street, DUMBO Industrial District, March 2008 | location= Roughly bounded by Main and Washington Sts, East River, John St., Bridge and Jay Sts., and Front and York Sts., [[Brooklyn, New York]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|42|11|N|73|59|17|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=inline}} | locmapin = New York City#New York#USA | built = 1883 | architect = multiple | architecture = Greek Revival, Italianate, et al. | added = September 22, 2000 | area = {{convert|48|acre}} | governing_body = Local | refnum = 00001151<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2009a}}</ref> }} }}
'''Dumbo''' (or '''DUMBO''',<ref name="dolkart"/><ref name="nyt2007-12-25">{{cite news |title=Dumbo Journal: District Trying to Forge a New Identity |first=Anne |last=Barnard |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/25/nyregion/25journal.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 25, 2007 |accessdate=September 6, 2015}}</ref> short for '''D'''own '''U'''nder the '''M'''anhattan '''B'''ridge '''O'''verpass) is a neighborhood in the [[New York City]] [[borough (New York City)|borough]] of [[Brooklyn]]. The area known as DUMBO used to be known as Gairville.<ref>{{cite news | first= David W. |last= Dunlap| title= SoHo, TriBeCa And Now Dumbo? |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/realestate/soho-tribeca-and-now-dumbo.html |work= New York Times |date=October 25, 1998 | accessdate=April 19, 2017}}</ref> It encompasses two sections: one located between the [[Manhattan Bridge|Manhattan]] and [[Brooklyn Bridge]]s, which connect Brooklyn to [[Manhattan]] across the [[East River]], and another that continues east from the Manhattan Bridge to the [[Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn|Vinegar Hill]] area. The neighborhood is bounded by [[Brooklyn Bridge Park]] to the north, the [[Brooklyn Bridge]] to the west, [[Brooklyn Heights]] to the south and Vinegar Hill to the east. Dumbo is part of [[Brooklyn Community Board 2]].
The area was originally a [[ferry]] landing, characterized by 19th- and early 20th-century industrial and warehouse buildings, [[Sett (paving)|Belgian block]] streets, and its location on the East River by the imposing anchorage of the Manhattan Bridge. The entirety of Dumbo was bought by developer [[David Walentas]] and his company Two Trees Management in the late 20th century, and remade into an upscale residential and commercial community—first becoming a haven for art [[Art museum|galleries]], and currently a center for technology [[Startup company|startups]].
The large community of tech startups earned DUMBO the nickname of "the center of the Brooklyn Tech Triangle". In that time, Dumbo had become Brooklyn's most expensive neighborhood, as well as New York City's fourth-richest community overall; this is owing in part to its large concentration of technology [[Startup company|startups]], its close proximity to Manhattan, and its large number of former industrial buildings that have been converted into spacious [[luxury real estate|luxury]] residential [[lofts]].<ref>{{cite web | last=Nonko | first=Emily | title=The 8 Most Expensive Neighborhoods in New York City | website=New York.com | date=January 27, 2015 | url=http://www.newyork.com/articles/real-estate/the-most-expensive-neighborhoods-in-new-york-city-75971 | accessdate=November 7, 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151029075613/http://www.newyork.com/articles/real-estate/the-most-expensive-neighborhoods-in-new-york-city-75971/ | archivedate=October 29, 2015 | df= }}</ref> The neighborhood is the corporate headquarters for e-commerce retailer [[Etsy]] and home furnishing stores company [[West Elm]].
==Name== {{stack|float=left| [[File:Street fair under the Manhattan Bridge overpass, July 2017.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|A [[street fair]] under the Manhattan Bridge overpass in July 2017|left]] [[File:Empire State framed by Manhattan Bridge July 2017.jpg|upright=1.3|left|thumb|The [[Manhattan Bridge]], framing the [[Empire State Building]] beneath, as seen from Washington Street]]}} The name is an [[acronym]] of "Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass". Several other New York City neighborhoods are known by [[portmanteau]]s, including [[Tribeca]], [[SoHo, Manhattan|SoHo]], [[NoHo, Manhattan|NoHo]], [[NoMad]], and [[Nolita]] in Manhattan, and [[BoCoCa]] in Brooklyn.<ref name="dolkart">{{Cite book |last1=Dolkart |first1=Andrew S. |url=http://home2.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/DUMBO_Designation_Report.pdf |title=DUMBO Historic District Designation Report |publisher=[[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] |date=December 18, 2007 |accessdate=September 6, 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="nyt2007-12-25"/>
==History== The area has been known variously as Rapailie, Olympia, and Walentasville.<ref name="DumboNYC">{{cite web |title=About Dumbo |url=http://dumbonyc.com/about |work=Dumbo NYC, Brooklyn |publisher=DumboNYC.com |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref> The "Olympia" name came from [[Comfort Sands|Comfort]] and [[Joshua Sands (politician)|Joshua Sands]], who bought the land in 1787<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Olympia Settlement in Early Brooklyn|last = |first = |publisher = |year = 1929|isbn = |location = New York|pages = }}</ref> and were planning to develop the land as a summer place for New Yorkers.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Dictionary of American Biography|last = Johnson|first = Allen|publisher = Charles Scribner’s Sons|year = 1964|isbn = |location = New York|pages = 341–342}}</ref> Through the 18th and 19th centuries, the area now known as Dumbo was considered part of [[Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn|Vinegar Hill]].<ref name="HISTORICAL DISTRICTS 1966">{{Cite journal|date=1966|title=HISTORICAL DISTRICTS|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/20780654|journal=Real Property, Probate and Trust Journal|volume=1|issue=3|pages=204–211}}</ref>
In the 1890s, the western portion of the neighborhood was known as [[Fulton Landing]], after the [[ferry]] stop that connected it to Manhattan before the [[Brooklyn Bridge]] opened. At that time, it was primarily a manufacturing district, with warehouses and factories that made machinery, paper boxes and [[Brillo]] soap pads. The area has been known variously as Rapailie, Olympia, and Walentasville.<ref name="DumboNYC"/> The [[cardboard box]] was invented in the Robert Gair building on Washington Street by Robert Gair, a Scottish emigrant; because of Gair's fame, the area was known as Gairsville for a long time.<ref name="DumboNYC"/> The Gair building is now home to [[Etsy]].<ref name="usa"/>>
The [[Jay Street Connecting Railroad]] ran through Dumbo's waterfront from circa 1904–1906 through 1957. It ran from rail yards beneath the Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges to buildings near the waterfront in Dumbo and Vinegar Hill. At the height of operations, it had spurs into several buildings, a [[car float bridge]] on Bridge Street, and a yard with capacity of 120 cars.<ref>{{cite web | title=Jay Street Terminal / Jay Street Connecting Railroad | website=TrainWeb.org | date=November 30, 2017 | url=http://members.trainweb.com/bedt/indloco/jst.html | access-date=November 28, 2018}}</ref><ref name=NYPress-JSC-2003>{{cite web|url=http://www.nypress.com/the-jay-street-connecting-railroad/|title=The Jay Street Connecting Railroad|first=William|last=Bryk|date=April 22, 2003|work=NY Press}}</ref> The tracks were abandoned in 1959,<ref>{{cite web | title=RAIL LINE TO END ITS BROOKLYN RUN; Jay Street Connecting Road Allowed to Discontinue Operations in Harbor | website=The New York Times | date=April 16, 1959 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1959/04/16/archives/rail-line-to-end-its-brooklyn-run-jay-street-connecting-road.html | access-date=November 28, 2018}}</ref> though the railroad's tracks are still visible on streets in Dumbo.<ref name=NYPress-JSC-2003/>
With the [[deindustrialization]] of New York City, Dumbo began to become primarily residential; artists and other young homesteaders seeking relatively large and inexpensive [[loft apartment]] spaces for studios and homes began moving there in the late 1970s.<ref name="nyt2007-12-25"/> The acronym "Dumbo" arose in 1978, when new residents coined it in the belief such an unattractive name would help deter developers.<ref name="nyt2007-12-25"/>
Near the end of the 20th century, as property became more and more expensive in Manhattan, Dumbo became increasingly [[gentrification|gentrified]]. Even so, the acronym 'Dumbo' was largely unknown as late as 1997, and the area itself was very inclusive, serving mainly as an enclave for artists located along the [[East River]] and under the [[Manhattan Bridge]]. At this stage there were still many air conditioner repair shops, auto shops, and "seedy back alleys and wharves"; and, because the neighborhood was still gentrifying from its industrial past, it lacked even a bookstore, coffee shop, or [[Self-service laundry|laundromat]].<ref name="nyt 19971010">[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE3DC153CF933A25753C1A961958260&pagewanted=all "As It Turns Artistic, A Noirish Enclave Steps Into the Light"]. October 10, 1997. ''New York Times'' article by Peter Marks; accessed November 12, 2010.</ref> The efforts of [[Joy Glidden]], the Founding Director of the Dumbo Arts Center (DAC) and co-founder of the Dumbo Art Under the Bridge Festival, achieved successful development in Dumbo, which is now a model for similar waterfront developments around the world.<ref>[http://soulofbrooklyn.com/neighborhoods/dumbo/ Dumbo - Soul of Brooklyn] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214045443/http://soulofbrooklyn.com/neighborhoods/dumbo/ |date=February 14, 2014 }}. "The DUMBO Arts Center was founded by Joy Glidden and under her direction from 1997-2006 has helped to establish a successful model for waterfront development that has been referred to and used internationally". Retrieved June 12, 2014.</ref> Glidden stated of Dumbo's gentrification, "It may be one of the last of what could be considered a true arts community in New York."<ref name="nyt 19971010"/>
The DUMBO Historic District, a historic industrial complex and national [[Historic district (United States)|historic district]] in Dumbo, was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2000.<ref name="nris"/> It consists of 95 contributing buildings; the manufacturing concerns located in this district included [[Benjamin Moore & Co.]] (paint), Arbuckle Brothers (coffee and sugar), J.W. Masury & Son (paint), Robert Gair (paper boxes), E.W. Bliss (machinery), and Brillo (soap pads). The district includes the earliest large-scale [[reinforced concrete]] factory buildings in America.<ref name="nrhpinv_ny">{{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3049|title=National Register of Historic Places Registration:DUMBO Industrial District|date=June 2000|accessdate=March 6, 2011|author=Kathy Howe|publisher=[[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019090418/http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3049|archivedate=October 19, 2012|df=}} ''See also:'' {{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3048|title=Accompanying 20 photos|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019090434/http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3048|archivedate=October 19, 2012|df=}}</ref> On December 18, 2007, the [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] voted unanimously to designate Dumbo as the city's 90th historic district. The Dumbo historic district consists of properties bound by John Street to the north, York Street to the south, Main Street to the west, and Bridge Street to the east.<ref>{{cite press release |publisher=[[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] |date=December 18, 2007 |format=PDF |title=Landmarks Preservation Commission Designates Dumbo as New York City's 90th Historic District |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/press/12_18_07.pdf |accessdate=July 3, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020232259/http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/press/12_18_07.pdf |archive-date=October 20, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Land use== {{stack|float=right|[[File:Plymouthst.JPG|upright|thumb|right|Looking westward from Jay Street along Plymouth Street, through Dumbo, under the Manhattan Bridge, at a pier of the [[Brooklyn Bridge]]]]}}
===Art, business, and leisure=== The area has emerged as one of New York City's premier arts districts, with a cluster of for-profit art galleries such as the Klompching Gallery, and such not-for-profit institutions as the [[St. Ann's Warehouse]] and the [[A.I.R. Gallery]].
Chef [[Chocolate with Jacques Torres|Jacques Torres]] opened a chocolate factory in Dumbo in December 2000.<ref>{{cite news |title='Mr Chocolate' blazed a sweet trail for retailers - Jacques Torres Chocolates |first=Peter |last=Moore |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3601/is_27_50/ai_113898100 |newspaper=Real Estate Weekly |date=February 18, 2004 |accessdate=July 3, 2010}}</ref> Other culinary businesses in the area include [[Grimaldi's]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Pizza Madness: Grimaldi Taking Over Grimaldi's When Grimaldi Moves Next Door |first=Joanna |last=Shaw |url=http://nonabrooklyn.com/pizza-madness-grimaldi-taking-over-grimaldis-when-grimaldis-moves-next-door/ |work=Nona Brooklyn |date=November 29, 2011 |accessdate=November 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111209084545/http://nonabrooklyn.com/pizza-madness-grimaldi-taking-over-grimaldis-when-grimaldis-moves-next-door/ |archivedate=December 9, 2011 |df= }}</ref> the [[Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/01/nyregion/neighborhood-report-fulton-ferry-some-landmarks-are-just-meant-to-be-a-problem.html |title=FULTON FERRY; Some Landmarks Are Just Meant to Be a Problem |publisher=The New York Times |date=February 1, 2004 |accessdate=April 29, 2011}}</ref> and The River Café,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://therivercafe.com|title=The River Café Restaurant - Brooklyn, New York - Established 1977|website=The River Café|accessdate=July 14, 2018}}</ref> all clustered in Fulton Landing, also home to [[Bargemusic]], a floating venue for classical music.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE3D9173BF933A1575BC0A967958260 |title=Music in Review |accessdate=August 4, 2008 |date=August 20, 1991 |author=Allan Kozinn |work=The New York Times}}</ref>
Invitations for the [[first inauguration of Barack Obama|2009 presidential inauguration]] of U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] were printed by Dumbo printer Precise Continental.<ref>{{cite news |title='Inside a Gritty Brooklyn Factory, Potomac Fever |first=Caroline |last=Dworin |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/21/nyregion/thecity/21prin.html |work=New York Times |date=December 19, 2008 |accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref>
The first public space in the neighborhood was [[Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn|Fulton Ferry]],<ref>{{cite web|title=New York Water Taxi Begins Service From Fulton Ferry |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/64607/new-york-water-taxi-begins-service-from-fulton-ferry |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130630011834/http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/64607/new-york-water-taxi-begins-service-from-fulton-ferry |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 30, 2013 |publisher=NY1 |accessdate=November 27, 2006 }}</ref> followed by [[Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Empire Fulton Ferry |url=http://www.brooklynbridgepark.org/the-park/empire-fulton-ferry-open |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014141311/http://www.brooklynbridgepark.org/the-park/empire-fulton-ferry-open |archivedate=October 14, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Calder |first=Rich |title=Brooklyn Bridge Park finally set to open |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/brooklyn_bridge_park_finally_set_bym9agsosKay1dnTONph0L |accessdate=October 24, 2013 |newspaper=New York Post |date=December 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118182829/http://www.nypost.com/p/brooklyn_bridge_park_finally_set_bym9agsosKay1dnTONph0L |archivedate=January 18, 2010 }}</ref> The first six acres of [[Brooklyn Bridge Park]], a joint state/city venture under development, were opened in March 2010.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Governor Paterson and Mayor Bloomberg Open First Section of Brooklyn Bridge Park |publisher=New York State |url=http://www.governor.ny.gov/archive/paterson/press/032210BrooklynBridgePark.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121214041818/http://www.governor.ny.gov/archive/paterson/press/032210BrooklynBridgePark.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 14, 2012 |date=March 22, 2010 |accessdate=April 4, 2012 }}</ref>
The building at 200 Water Street, which the Brillo Manufacturing Co. once occupied, is being renovated as a high-end condo building.<ref>{{Cite news |title=In Dumbo, a Study in Industrial Chic |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-dumbo-a-study-in-industrial-chic-1449708719 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal|access-date = December 11, 2015 |issn=0099-9660 |first=Josh |last=Barbanel}}</ref>
{{Clear left}}
===Tech hub=== {{see also|New York Digital District}} Dumbo has New York City's highest concentration of technology firms by neighborhood.<ref name="usa">Graham, Jefferson. (May 7, 2013). ''It's hip to be tech in Brooklyn's Dumbo''. USA TODAY, p 5B.</ref> Dumbo is home to 25 percent of New York City-based tech firms. Within a 10-block radius are 500 tech and creative firms that employ over 10,000 people.<ref name="usa"/> It also contains the corporate headquarters for e-commerce retailer [[Etsy]]<ref>[Goodman, Wendy. [http://nymag.com/thecut/2014/08/etsy-office-tour.html "See Inside Etsy’s Seriously Fun Brooklyn Office"], ''[[New York (magazine)]]'', August 14, 2014. Accessed September 27, 2016. "The other day, I took a tour of Etsy's Dumbo offices and was pleased to find them as original, wacky, and one-of-a-kind as a workplace can get."</ref> and home furnishing stores company [[West Elm]].<ref>Gurfein, Laura. [http://ny.racked.com/2015/1/13/7561379/west-elm-dumbo "Here's the First Look at West Elm's New Dumbo Home"], [[Racked.com]], January 13, 2015. Accessed September 27, 2016.</ref>
[[File:Pearl Street Pocket Park.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.1|Pearl Street [[pocket park]] in Dumbo]] The City of New York, in conjunction with [[New York University]], installed an incubator in Dumbo to support development of tech start-ups.<ref name="usa"/> Dumbo's average office rent of $25 per square foot makes it more attractive to start-ups than Manhattan, where rents averaged $40 per square foot in 2013.<ref name="usa"/> The area has been compared to the [[Silicon Roundabout]] area in [[Shoreditch]], [[East London]], as well as to Manhattan's [[Silicon Alley]].
===Transportation=== [[New York City Subway]] stations are located at [[York Street (IND Sixth Avenue Line)|York Street]] ({{NYCS trains|Sixth far south}}) on the [[IND Sixth Avenue Line]], and [[High Street (IND Eighth Avenue Line)|High Street]] ({{NYCS trains|Cranberry}}) on the [[IND Eighth Avenue Line]].<ref>{{NYCS const|map}}</ref> [[New York City Bus]] service is provided by the {{NYC bus link|B25|B67|B69}}.<ref>{{Cite NYC bus map|B}}</ref>
Ramps and staircases connect the Brooklyn Bridge and Manhattan Bridge walkways to Dumbo.
In June 2011, [[NY Waterway]] started service to points along the East River.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/14/nyregion/east-river-ferry-service-begins-with-7-stops.html|title=East River Ferry Service Begins|last=Grynbaum|first=Michael M.|date=June 13, 2011|last2=Quinlan|first2=Adriane|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=September 23, 2016}}</ref> On May 1, 2017, that route became part of the [[NYC Ferry]]'s East River route, which runs between [[Pier 11/Wall Street]] in Manhattan's [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] and the [[East 34th Street Ferry Landing]] in [[Murray Hill, Manhattan]], with five intermediate stops in Brooklyn and Queens. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/new-york/nyc-launches-ferry-service-queens-east-river-routes-article-1.3122046|title=NYC launches ferry service with Queens, East River routes|date=May 1, 2017|website=NY Daily News|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=May 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170501154444/http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/new-york/nyc-launches-ferry-service-queens-east-river-routes-article-1.3122046|archivedate=May 1, 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/01/nyregion/new-york-today-citywide-ferry-service-begins.html|title=New York Today: Our City’s New Ferry|last=Levine|first=Alexandra S.|date=May 1, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=May 1, 2017|last2=Wolfe|first2=Jonathan|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> One of the East River Ferry's stops is at [[Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn|Fulton Ferry]] in Dumbo.<ref name=east-river>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ferry.nyc/routes-and-schedules/route/east-river/|title=Routes and Schedules: East River|publisher=NYC Ferry}}</ref>
===Housing=== The neighborhood contains the [[Farragut Houses]], a group of ten towers managed by the [[New York City Housing Authority]].<ref name=Nation5613>{{cite news |title=Welcome to the Gilded City of New York |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/173892/welcome-gilded-city-new-york |accessdate=April 18, 2013 |newspaper=The Nation |date=April 17, 2013 |author=The Editors}}</ref>
==In popular culture== {{stack|float=right| [[File:Dumbo clean kortune.jpg|upright=0.6|thumb|right|[[Kortunefookie]] at ''Art Under The Bridge'' in Dumbo]] }} * [[Jerry Seinfeld]] referred to Dumbo on a late-night talk show appearance, joking that it stands for "Down Under Manhattan Bridge", but that New Yorkers added the "O" at the end because they did not want to live in a neighborhood called "Dumb".<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4zzRAPW9hWo#t=27s Jerry Seinfeld episode from 2001]. ''The reference to Dumbo can be heard at the 0:26 mark in the video.''</ref> * [[Tracy Bonham]] wrote a song about her years in Dumbo on her CD ''[[Blink the Brightest]]'', "Dumbo Sun".{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * The neighborhood is parodied in ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'' as BOABO ("Beneath the Off-ramp of the Algonquin Bridge Overpass").{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * It is featured as a filming location in the films ''[[Killer's Kiss]]'' (1955), ''[[The French Connection (film)|The French Connection]]'' (1971), and ''[[Vanilla Sky]]'' (2001). It is also featured in [[Big Bang (South Korean band)|Big Bang]]'s music video ''Blue'' (2012), the music video for "Cruel Summer" by [[Bananarama]] (1983) and the opening credits of ''[[Rescue Me (U.S. TV series)|Rescue Me]]'' (2004).{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * It is the residence of the Humphrey family in the television series ''[[Gossip Girl]]''. The view from Washington Street appears very often to inform the viewer of the scenario change from Manhattan to Brooklyn.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * Dumbo is the inspiration of Nacrene City in the ''[[Pokémon Black and White]]'' games.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * Dumbo is featured prominently in the [[Sergio Leone]] drama film ''[[Once Upon a Time in America]]'' as the location for one of its scenes.<ref name="The Worldwide Guide to Movie Locations">{{cite web | title=Filming Locations for Sergio Leone's epic Once Upon a Time in America (1983), in New York, New Jersey, Florida, Quebec, Paris and Venice. | website=The Worldwide Guide to Movie Locations | url=http://www.movie-locations.com/movies/o/Once-Upon-A-Time-In-America.php | access-date=2018-07-14}}</ref> * Dumbo appears in ''[[Law and Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' as a site of a runaway girl and a rave in season two.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * Dumbo appears in the show ''[[Orange Is the New Black]]'' in the episode "Toast Can't Never Be Bread Again", the [[List of Orange Is the New Black episodes#Season 4 (2016)|fourth season's finale]], as part of a flashback sequence of Poussey Washington's past, in which she is separated from her friends and meets some drag artists who take her to a party in a club in Dumbo.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} * Dumbo is referenced on the [[Jay-Z]] track ''[[The Story of O.J.]]'' on the album [[4:44 (album)|4:44]], as Shawn Carter raps about a missed opportunity when he was younger to purchase a now valuable building in the neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/02/arts/music/jay-z-4-44-review.html|title=Jay-Z Revels in the Catharsis of Confession on ‘4:44’|author=Jon Caramanica|date=Jul 2, 2017|publisher=New York Times|quote=When he laments not investing in the now-redeveloped Brooklyn neighborhood Dumbo on “The Story of O. J.,” it’s not clever, just a gripe. And one delivered without much flair.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/30/3-money-lessons-from-jay-zs-444.html|title=3 money lessons from Jay-Z's '4:44'|author=Courtney Connley|publisher=CNBC|date=Jun 30, 2017|quote=On this track, the rapper bemoans rising real estate values in his home city}}</ref> {{clear}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Dumbo, Brooklyn}} * [https://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2007/10/29/nyregion/20071029_DUMBO_SLIDESHOW_index.html Discovering Dumbo Slideshow], ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 29, 2007
{{Brooklyn}}
